InsightThapana SirivadhanabhakdiPresident and CEO As CEO my job is to create value from growth and share the opportunities with our stakeholders especially employees. It is truly our intention when we say there are limitless opportunities at ThaiBev.ThaiBev believes that the happiness and advancement of employees are important motivating factors for them to stay with the organization for the long term. Therefore ThaiBev has continued to provide such opportunities to its employees. As a result ThaiBevs employees are capable and work happily with the organization for a long time. In addition they are able to create the foundation for growth strengthening the organization and its corporate culture. ThaiBev has seven strategies of human capital management as followsStrategy Clear Structure and Roles Arrange organizational structure to be in line with the roles and responsibilities to achieve the goals of Vision and for the future. Strategy Marketoriented Compensation and Benefits Continuously monitor changes in the job market and the needs of personnel to analyze compensation and benefits in order to create appropriate standards for ThaiBev Groups companies.Strategy Recognitionbased Performance ManagementBuild a comprehensive employee performance management system and expand the systems accessibility to meet the needs of employees in each age range. Provide fair evaluation as well as development planning to unlock employees potential enbling them to work towards their goals and achieve excellence.Strategy Holistic People DevelopmentPromote a learning culture for employees to develop their capabilities. ThaiBev uses the principle of developing employees potential according to the model for learning and development. It also promotes the development of digital technology skills and the implementation of the individual development plan IDP as well as employee progress tracking.Strategy Proactive Succession and Workforce Planning Proactively prepare the readiness of employees and executives identified as potential successors to ensure semless transition and business continuity enhancing sustainability of the organization.Strategy Strategic Talent Acquisition and OnboardingDevelop the recruitment process and the selection of personnel with appropriate knowledge ability and skills to perform the job as desired by the organization as well as projects to reach and attract potential candidates to join the organization especially new generations who are looking for an organization that is agile and capable of adapting in the digital age.Strategy Engaging Corporate CultureBuild knowledge understanding and engagement by strengthening a sense of oneness through the global values of the ThaiBev Group promoting employees continuous engagement to encourage appropriate behavior according to corporate values.

Access to safe water is a fundamental human right and it is essential to the wellbeing of communities and the environment. Water Stewardship WHY IT MATTERS Access to safe water is a fundamental human right and it is essential to the wellbeing of communities and the environment. It is also necessary for mines smelters processing facilities and reclamation projects. Eective management of water resources can reduce the impact of mining activities on water availability and quality while respecting the rights of others. OUR APPROACH Water is essential to our work and vital to the longterm sustainability of the company and our host communities. We cannot operate without water and Freeport understands the critical importance of managing the impacts of our activities on water availability and quality and respecting the rights of our host communities and Indigenous neighbors. Freeports water stewardship program focuses on maximizing our water use eciency within our operations so that we can minimize our use of new freshwater taken from the natural environment. We are also focused on shifting our water supplies to more sustainable sources recycled reused renewable and lower quality sources minimizing negative impacts from our operations on water quality and availability in the local catchments and supporting the development of access to previously unknown unavailable or undeveloped water resources. In addition to focusing on our own waterrelated supply risks surrounding our operations water stewardship also means we are focused on promoting longterm water security for all. We recognize the importance of working collaboratively with our stakeholders to secure access to water in a socially and environmentally responsible manner and we are dedicated to continuously improving our water programs over time. The global nature of our operations requires a tailored sitespecic approach to our water strategy. Many of our operations are in arid environments where there is signicant competition for water. Conversely our Colorado and Indonesia operations present a dierent challenge receiving so much rainfall that considerable eort goes into managing excess water supply.

The Schaeer Group takes a holistic approach to developing innovative product solutions for the demands of the future from climate friendly energy generation and alternative drives to intelligent repair solutions and new mobility concepts. For example Schaeer Industrial increases energy eciency in wind turbines with its low friction bearings. Automotive Technologies develops alternative drive technologies that help reduce the average CO emissions of vehicles. Automotive Aftermarket solutions extend the life cycle of vehicles in accordance with the latest environmental standards. With its products and solutions the company helps its customers to achieve their climate goals. Customers and products The products of the Schaeer Group directly contribute to achieving the Sustainable Development Goals SDGs. For example energy chain products help to achieve the goal of Aordable and Clean Energy SDG. Predictive maintenance and industrial bearing solutions enable resilient and sustainable Industry Innovation and Infrastructure SDG. Technical innovations for electrically powered cars scooters eboards and ebikes encourage the development of Sustainable Cities and Communities SDG.. Innovative mobility and industrial solutions . CO efficient drives . Chassis applications . Industrial machinery and equipment . Renewable energy . Aftermarket solutions and services . Product quality and safety .

MMC FIRST PROCESS AND THOSE AROUND US We depend on a large array of partners suppliers and experts to create our solutions. We also want to give something back to the communities we operate. Therefore this section is divided in two the innovation process and the knowledge sharing with other communities. COOPERATION INNOVATION Multiple disciplines and specialists are required to ensure we improve our products and services. We work with the research community to better understand the effects our products have on sh. We work closely with our customers and are able to draw on their expertise. Below is the story of how we created and installed our solutions for a British customer. Cutting pumping systems to secure sh welfare In we launched a new patented sh pump to improve sh welfare. In June researchers from Sintef Ocean visited our test plant at our site in Aalesund. They ran tests using sh with sensors attached to measure and analyse any pressure surges and shocks through the pump. Prior to this we had also run tests using delicate foods such as tomatoes eggs and cucumbers etc. We have worked closely and effectively with Sintef Ocean and Mreforskning throughout the project and all of us have gained valuable knowledge Having these research resources available in our network is important in our endeavour to be a world leader in the handling of live sh.

HEALTH PROTECTION AND OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY Creating a work environment that is conducive to the health of its employees and taking precautions to protect them from possible accidents and injuries is a key responsibility for every company. To fulfil this responsibility and retain the individual worker Semperit has installed a health and safety management system that is continuously being further developed. The coronavirus pandemic continues to be challenging. Semperit nevertheless continued to successfully avoid contagion in the workplace in and maintained smooth operations through consistent measures. The topics of health protection and occupational safety are consolidated organisationally with environment and quality within HSEQ Health Safety Environment and Quality. The HSEQ Policy which is publicly available on the Semperit website defines the Groupwide policies in connection with these topics. An HSE Health Safety and Environment manager at each location performs all activities on site from information and training to the documentation of incidents. The local managers report to the Director of HSEQ who in turn reports to the Executive Board at monthly meetings. This ensures that the effectiveness of the management system and that of the associated processes and measures are continuously monitored and safeguarded from the highest level. Integrating relevant HSEQ key figures into the individual target agreements with management is an essential measure to support health protection and occupational safety. This initiative was launched in and further expanded in.

ENVIRONMENTMARKETSWORKPLACECOMMUNITYSocial Mobility EducationCivic ContributionHuman RightsClimate EnergyConsumption Waste Natural Resources Service ExcellenceEthics IntegrityGovernance Transparency Talent Performance Diversity InclusionHealth Safety Wellbeing We have a longstanding commitment to responsible business which for us is about how we collaborate with our clients give back to the community respect the environment and create an inclusive and engaging workplace. Our responsible business framework reflects how our business people community and environment interconnect. It allows us to focus on the activities that are most important to our firm and our stakeholders as a responsible business and towards a sustainable future. We strive for best practice and to support this we are a signatory to the UN Global Compact a member of Business in the Community BITC and have integrated the UN Sustainable Development Goals SDGs into our responsible business strategy. We participate in the BITC Responsible Business Tracker to drive continuous improvement. In the first formal year of the new benchmark we are pleased to have achieved a score of which was above the average of all participants and placed us firmly within the legal sector cohort.Our responsible business approach UN Sustainable Development GoalsTo engage with the UN Sustainable Development Goals SDGs we initially undertook a mapping and materiality exercise to understand their relevance and our key impacts. Whilst all the SDGs are important we found that ten resonated more strongly. It is with reference to these ten SDGs that we have defined our five responsible business objectives. This in turn provides a strategic direction for what we do internally the contribution of our legal expertise the building of external relationships and the development of our performance measures and targets. During the year we undertook a series of formal stakeholder engagements on our approach our framework our performance the integration of the SDGs and our five overarching responsible business objectives. We have used the objectives as the main structure for this report and cover feedback from our stakeholder engagements in the section entitled Collaboration and collective impact.

ANNUAL REPORT ON SUSTAINABILITY Business Integrity Freeport is committed to the highest level of ethical and legal conduct in all of our business activities. Acting ethically involves more than simply complying with laws and regulations it involves recognition that our decisions aect others. By keeping this in mind we aspire to earn the respect trust and condence of our stakeholders. AntiCorruption Compliance WHY IT MATTERS Engaging in corruption or bribery is not only illegal but can permanently damage a companys business relationships and workforce morale. Freeport recognizes that any violation of the United States Foreign Corrupt Practices Act FCPA or other anticorruption and antibribery laws of the jurisdictions in which we operate could result in signicant criminal or civil nes and penalties litigation loss of operating licenses or permits as well as signicant reputational damage. OUR APPROACH Freeport maintains zero tolerance for corruption of any kind and we expect the same from our employees contractors and suppliers. We do not obtain a business advantage through bribery improper payments kickbacks or any other illegal means. No employee or contractor may oer pay solicit or accept bribes in any form. Our AntiCorruption Policy and Guidelines require compliance with the FCPA and other applicable laws of the countries and jurisdictions where we operate. In addition to our annual PBC training we provide annual anticorruption training for specic groups of employees using a risk based approach. For example seniorlevel employees who may interact with government ocials are required to complete the training. The online training course supplements our inperson classroom training programs to extend the reach of our overall compliance eorts. In recognition of the potential legal and reputational liability that could result from actions of our business partners and contractors under the FCPA and other laws the company operates an online due diligence platform the Freeport Compliance eXchange FCeX. FCeX is a surveybased software platform designed to assess risk in the areas of anticorruption international trade human rights and responsible minerals sourcing. FCeX enhances our ability to identify assess and mitigate compliance risks. Annually we perform companywide program and risk assessments with assistance from our internal audit rm Deloitte to assess risk and plan for the following years audit strategy. Business controls resulting from periodic fraud risk assessments are tested and reviewed annually at our corporate oces as well as at PTFI Cerro Verde El Abra and Atlantic Copper.

SUSTAINABILITY I ICELANDAIR ANNUAL REPORT New goals of reducing carbon emissions Our goals of reducing emissions are in line with the airline industrys goals. Facing a transition that is challenging we have in addition now set new specific targets for reducing emissions by. Reaching these goals will require continued efforts through a combination of measures such as fleet renewal operational improvements the implementation of sustainable aviation fuels as well as carbon offsetting. The implementation of the Boeing MAX aircrafts into our fleet is an important contributor to reducing our emissions in addition to the operational efficiencies that they bring to our business. Reducing CO emissions target year reduction in net emissions per OTK compared to Net Zero emissions from flight operations reduction of emissions from ground vehicles compared to OTK operational tonne kilometre The key metric that is used to monitor environmental impact is CO per Operational ton kilometer OTK. The OTK metric displays how much CO is emitted by moving one payload ton the weight of the aircraft passengers and cargo one kilometer. Cargo transport low carbon footprint of fresh fish Demand for cargo remained strong in and the Company kept the focus on meeting it protecting important export from Iceland and importing necessities to the country. A key focus area in our cargo services is ensuring efficient transport of fresh Icelandic seafood and thus supporting important export revenue generation in Iceland. Utilizing our strong route network we work closely with our partners to deliver fresh seafood products that have a low carbon footprint compared to other protein sources and can be ready on consumers plates in diverse markets within hours of being caught. Offsetting program Icelandair has offered passengers the option to offset the carbon footprint of their air travel since September. Even though the Covid pandemic still had an impact on traveling passengers still participated in the compensation of their carbon footprint and contributed to the planting of around trees during the year. The carbon offset program was devised in cooperation with Klappir Green Solutions and Kolvidur the Iceland Carbon Fund to cultivate forests in Iceland. Icelandair offsets all employee business travel. Support of Green by Iceland Grnvangur Green by Iceland is a publicprivate partnership set up to promote green climate solutions. Participants are all working towards solutions for a more sustainable world. In Iceland many challenges have been addressed by utilizing the countrys natural resources. Icelands electricity production comes from renewable energy sources and houses get heating from geothermal district heating. Icelandic expertise can potentially help other countries to reduce their carbon emissions. In Icelandair became one of Grnvangurs sponsors.

The backbone of society and the basis of self -sufficiency is agricultural progress of food, fiber, fuel and industry. Furthermore, with the increase in human populations and climate pressure, the need to increase the safety of food production and the water conservation measures is imminent. By emulating the productivity of natural ecosystems and restoring carbon -based materials in the soil, agricultural production can be improved with a reduced dependence on potentially dusty and often prohibitively expensive synthetic fertilizers. Through various cases of study that show the effectiveness of educational tools, we work to demonstrate the need for greater financial investments in the development of the biomass use program in order to cultivate emerging circular economies. Given the above, this document should be considered as one step further in the design process that can inspire the official SDG review process. The innovation and complexity of the SDG framework opens a wide range of research paths, of which we emphasize three. First, the threshold prices proposed here do not say much about whether countries are on the right track to achieve SDG-2 goals unless they are monitored for a longer period. Although SDG targets are the same for all countries, the roads that follow will vary. Historical trends can offer advice on the future of a country, but there is no guarantee that previous trends will remain. Secondly, synergies and compromises on all SDGs and detailed scales must be examined to be informed of cohesive policy planning under different scenarios. Thirdly, the agricultural trade between the countries considered in this document is worth more attention and has a direct impact on the nutrition and environmental indicators, especially when food access and availability are considered in a short period of time and long -term conditions. In all cases, the recognition of research methodologies is suitable for tackling the spatial and temporal scalable complexity of viability objectives are vital.

Fishing grants are harmful to the fishing stock due to unsustainable fishing. Fishing stock exhausts due to human intervention. This can lead to massive harmful effects on humanity due to the boom of jellyfish. Fishing grants have been identified as the key factor in the exhaustion of species around the world due to the increase in industrial fishing. There has been a large gap between developed countries and developing countries in terms of fisheries in recent decades, it has deep consequences on industrial and craft fishing. The objective of the study is to show that the increase in fisheries subsidies has led to increasing endangered species in developed countries and in developed countries. The study performs OLS regression models to justify the objectives.

In order to reduce poverty and achieve target 1 of the 2030 Agenda for sustainable development, the foreign trade flows of the countries must be a driving force for the production activity, as proposed by the aid guided by the WTO for the commercial initiative. This work analyzes the evolution of the international trade of goods and services between less developed countries and customers of Africa and suppliers from other countries between 2005 and 2015, based on the information provided by Unctad and World Bank. The results confirm a greater degree of commercial opening and in particular an increase in imports of services. Overall, the data show that the purchases made on the international market have a greater marginal effect on GDP compared to sales, bringing to the conclusion that changes in commercial policy are needed, both internationally and nationally. The actions should be aimed at ensuring that the growing integration of these economies in the world commercial system does not cause continuous deficits in commercial balance but, on the contrary, contributes to the growth of GDP and the reduction of poverty.

We have developed a conceptual framework that colonized important indicators for SDG 1 progress in tuberculosis incidence of well -described risk factor paths with data from the SDG data repository and the WHO tuberculosis database for 192 countries with data. Correlations and mediation analyzes formed the strength of the association between the SDG 1 divisions and tuberculosis incidence, which led to a simplified framework for modeling. The simplified framework linked key indicators for SDG 1 directly with tuberculosis incidence. We have applied an exponential decay model based on linear associations between SDG 1 indicators and tuberculosis incidence to estimate the incidence of tuberculosis in 2035.

Goal 2 sustainable development 2 refers to the termination of hunger, the achievement of nutritional security and the improvement of nutrition and promoting sustainable agriculture. The SDGs mention only a few political indicators, and in particular SDG2 is largely without political considerations to end hunger and achieve nutritional safety. The Nobel Prize winner Amartya Sen observed the lack of famine in democracies, which indicates that a democratic system offers reviews that prevent famine. His observation has triggered further debates and triggered empirical studies in recent years. In this essay beyond the hypothesis of sen examines and examines other political factors that declare susceptibility to famine and have to be addressed explicitly in SDG 2 and similar initiatives. By taking over the case of pastoralists in the Afar region of Ethiopia, this research examines selected political determinants of famine. The Eritrea Ethiopia War and the resulting border closure have adversely released the livelihood of pastoralists in Asten-many pastoralists were withdrawn from a market and a reliable source of income. In addition, Aist pastoralists from the informal salt sector to which they had previously rely on were selected from the sore salt sector. The state made this expropriation easier and made the pastoralists even more susceptible to famine. I argue that political considerations are crucial to successfully end hunger and achieve nutritional safety. The essay uses a qualitative case study design and is based on a doctoral thesis.

The 2030 program recognizes that the eradication of poverty in all its forms and dimensions, including extreme poverty, is the largest global challenge and an essential requirement for sustainable development. ||| The first objective of sustainable development aims to "put an end to poverty in all its forms everywhere". Its seven associated targets aim, among other things, to eradicate extreme poverty for all people everywhere, reduce at least half of men, women and children of all ages living in poverty and implement systems of social protection Appropriate at the national level for all, including the floors, and by 2030, make substantial coverage of the poor and vulnerable ||| As recalled by the foreword report of the 2015 millennium development objectives report, during the Millennium Summit in September 2000, 189 countries unanimously adopted the Millennium Declaration, promising | || This commitment was translated by a framework inspiring with eight goals and, then, in large -scale practical stages that allowed people around the world to improve their lives and their future prospects. The MDGs have helped to raise more than a billion people to extreme poverty, to make breakthroughs against hunger, to allow more girls to go to school than ever before and to protect our planet. ||| Nevertheless, despite all the remarkable gains, the inequalities have persisted and the progress has been unequal. Consequently, the 2030 agenda for sustainable development and its set of sustainable development objectives have been committed, as indicated in the Declaration of the agenda, "to rely on the achievements of the millennial development objectives And try to attack their unfinished affairs ”. || | The theme of the 2017 high level political forum was ||| ", and he included SDG 1 as one of the ODD Focus ||| in" The Future We Wante the need to grant the greatest priority to the eradication of poverty within the United Nations Development Agenda , addressed the deep causes and the challenges of poverty through integrated, coordinated and consistent strategies at all levels. ||| In the context of the multi -year work program, adopted by the Sustainable Development Commission, held in March 1995 in Copenhagen. Being the biggest gathering of world leaders at the time, this event represented a crucial step and has committed to conquering poverty, the Goa L of full employment and the promotion of stable, safe and fair objectives of development. Chapter 2 is entirely devoted to the eradication of poverty with particular attention to the strategies to be adopted to obtain concrete results in this issue, to improve access to productive resources and infrastructure, to meet the fundamental human needs of all and improve social protection and reduce vulnerability. ||| Chapter 3 of the agenda describes poverty as "a complex multidimensional problem with origins in national and international fields". The agenda notes that no uniform solution can be found for the global application and identifies specific programs in the country to fight.

Tailings management why it is important that tailings and identifier management is fundamental for mining to safely protect people and the environment and maintain the social license to operate. The tailings are natural or by -products rock particles of Nelly Ground natural that remain after economically valuable minerals have been prosecuted and extracted from the mining mineral. In general, tailings are transported from processing facilities to management and storage facilities. We recognize that the possible failure of tailings facilities and other reservoirs in any of our mining operations could cause severe properties and in some cases catastrophic and environmental damage, as well as the loss of lives. Our approach to the health and safety of our communities for the reception of the workforce and the environment are fundamental for our extensive program and tailings management approach. Our goal is to have zero catastrophic failures and zero unplanned downloads of any of our tailings facilities. Freeport has comprehensive measures to ensure that our facilities are designed operated and monitored to minimize the risk for employees of neighboring host communities and the environment. These measures include a technological monitoring of substantial internal and external engineering, including the local responsibility for remote sensing and supervision of the third corporate and independent party. Our safeguards are generally within four categories that include good engineering practices and safe designs of rigorous adhesion to construction and operational parameters through monitoring and the use of technology supervision and adherence to practices based on continuous improvement and Learning past experiences, including industry failures and best practices. The safeguards are implemented identifier through the promotion of open and continuous communication throughout the organization and action at all levels. We continue to focus on the safe execution of our tailings management systems through interdisciplinary collaborations in our corporate sites and OCE. We organize workshops information sessions and training for our tailings engineers. These events support our teams with the exchange of knowledge in all places and provide opportunities to collaborate and develop relationships throughout the organization.

We have developed a conceptual framework that connects the basic indicators of SDG 1 progress on the impact of tuberculosis through the danger factor -described factor and we have secured it with data from the SDG data repository and the WHO Tuberculosis database for 192 countries. Mediation correlations and analyzes have informed the power of correlation between SDG 1 subsets and the impact of tuberculosis, resulting in a simplified framework for modeling. Since Kenya endeavors to maintain the dynamics in his race for sustainable development by 2030, his situation in nutritional certainty remains precarious. If Kenya should not achieve hunger by 2030, efforts must be required to scale the profits achieved. Currently, the effects of climate socket, covid-19, grasshopper invasion and an economy that does not grow as expected, continue to worsen nutritional uncertainty. While it has achieved the long-term rainfall over the years, these profits are lost due to an economy that fluctuates and due to the violence after the 2007/2008 election and now even more because of Covid 19. This weak economy works a negative approach to access, not only for food, but also availability. It is estimated that by the end of this year many Kenyans will be unsure of food that need humanitarian aid. While the majority of Kenyans have access to food, it still cannot fulfill the recommended rations. Many Kenyans have access to foods that are affordable, which makes less and less nutrition. Although Kenya is currently an income industry with a lower mean, it still has an estimated 238,000 in the emergency phase. Dry and semi-arid countries have the highest food uncertainty. The change in climate patterns has led to poor performance of the short rains. Climate change has a negative impact on the already fragile situation of nutritional security. The increasing level of food uncertainty threatens to negate profits in Kenya's progress towards zero hunger. While the challenges continue to exist, the United Nations' World Food Program works together with the Kenya government to improve efforts to build up a sustainable food system that will ensure sustainability in food and nutritional security in Kenya. Therefore, this study tries to evaluate the role of WFP when reaching SDG 2 in Kenya. The study was based on primary and secondary data.

The report examines the interactions between the various objectives and objectives, determining to what extent they strengthen or are in conflict with each other. It provides a model to help countries implement and achieve sustainable development objectives. This brief description of SDG 2 - "Entry Level Objective" for this evaluation - is followed by an overview of the objective interactions between SDG 2 and the other 16 SDGs. Taking into account all the underlying objectives of this entry objective, a series of key interactions is therefore identified between the SDG 2 objectives and those of other SDGs, focusing on interactions with high size or strong impacts based on the available scientific literature and the knowledge of the experts. The type and the seven -point staircase to characterize the interval of positive and negative interactions described in the opening chapter to this relationship are used to evaluate the selected target level interactions and the context in which they occur in general. Illustrative examples of different regions of the world show how these connections are manifested in practice. Political options that can improve and reduce negative interactions between today and 2030 and beyond are also described. The chapter ends with a list of key gaps relating to the interactions studied.

The livelihoods of more than 30 percent of the total population in India that reside in nine maritime states and four union territories depend on the various ecosystem services offered by coastal and marine systems. Marine fisheries contribute significantly to the Indian economy through seafood export currencies, which corresponds to almost 5 percent of the general export and 20 percent of the export agroes. In recent times, anthropogenic pressures due to extensive marine fishing introduce challenges in the marine environment. Marine anthropogehology, capable of transforming the natural configuration of the continental platform, is often not studied in detail from the perspective of sustainable fishing. For example, the use of varied fishing gears can damage the bottom of the sea, apart from the capture of youth and non -objective fish. The drag -mechanized crafts background as part of marine fishing affects the geomorphology of the continental platform and the continental slope by displacing the rocks, interrupting the structure of the sediment column, the resuspendent sediments and printing deep holes in the muddy background . Occasionally, the abandoned fishing networks/gears are also responsible for geomorphological damage at the bottom of the sea and the death of several marine bentonic flora and fauna, a phenomenon known as "ghost fishing." In addition, illegal, not informed and not regulated is the Nodal Agency, which disseminates the advice of PFZ since 1999 using data sets remotely of the sea surface and chlorophyll-a to reduce uncertainty during marine fishing. PFZ's warning can help promote environmental fishing reducing search time and, therefore, guaranteeing minimal damage to the marine environment.

Annual report on sustainability tailings administration because it imports the health and safety of our workforce host communities and the environment are fundamental to extensive Freeports tailings management programs. Tailings are particles or underproducts of natural rocks of the soil that remain after economically valuable minerals have been processed and extracted from the mined ore. Normally, our tailings comprise a Nely's natural rock particle folder, which are transported from processing facilities for management and storage facilities. We recognize that a failure in tailings and other damages in any of our mining operations can cause severe and, in some cases, catastrophic properties and environmental damage, as well as loss of life. Our Freeport approach has comprehensive measures to ensure that our facilities are designed operated and monitored to minimize the risk for neighboring host communities and the environment. We have a strong commitment to our Board and Executive Management to provide the financial and technical resources necessary to maintain the security of our facilities and the integrity of our tailings management systems, focusing on continuous improvement. Our tailings management and management program involving qualified external engineers of registration and periodic supervision of independent review councils and management teams adhere to applicable regulations and various national and international guidelines. The program is also in accordance with the tailings governance structure to prevent the catastrophic failure of our tailings storage facilities adopted in December by ICMM. As ICMM members, we support development and commit to working to implement the industry's new global pattern on tailings management, the tailings pattern. The tailings pattern was developed through an independent process of multistolas coconuted by the principles of the United Nations Environmental Program for responsible investment and ICMM after collapse of tragic tailings facilities in Brumadinho Brazil. Through our members, ICMM Freeport has played an active leadership role and provided constructive contributions to the development of the tailings pattern. Formally launched in August the tailings standard is the first global tailings management standard that can be applied to existing and future tailings installations. The tailings pattern has been integrated with ICMMS existing members' commitments and ICMM members have agreed that all riot facilities with extreme or very high consequence classifications need to demonstrate compliance with the tailings pattern within three years to August and all Other tailings facilities within the years by VE for VE by August. Freeport is currently advancing in internal plans to fulfill this commitment. Also in Freeport chaired a subgroup of the ICMM tailings working group to develop a guide to identify and recommend best practices for the practical implementation of the tailings pattern.

This article begins with the emphasis on the strengths of the goals for sustainable development, the international measures against poverty between 2000 and 2015 headed SDGS make important progress towards the MDGs, they are impaired by weakly formulated goals that give little indication of how the goal achieves becomes and by whom. The article further argues this fundamental mistake, reflects two deeper, fundamental problems that apply to the SDGs as a whole. The first is that the SDGs make it easier for governments to slowly realize human rights, and the second is that the SDGs do not indicate a clear division of labor, which requires severe poverty for a human rights obligation.

The ocean covers 70 percent of the earth's surface, is the largest biosphere of the planet and houses up to 80 percent of the world's life. It generates 50 percent of the oxygen that we need absorbs 25 percent of all carbon dioxide emissions and captures 90 percent of the additional heat that is generated from these emissions. It is not only "the planet's lungs", but also its largest carbon sisten - an important buffer against the effects of climate change. It promotes the unimaginable biological diversity and produces food, jobs, mineral and energy resources that are needed for life on the planet to survive and thrive. There is a lot that we still don't know anything about the ocean, but there are many reasons why we have to cope with their sustainability - as in the goals of sustainable development, goal 14: life under water. Science is clear - the ocean is due to unprecedented threats as a result of human activities. His health and ability to maintain life will only worsen when the world population grows and human activities increase. If we want to address some of the most decisive problems of our time, such as climate change, nutritional uncertainty, diseases and pandemics, reduced biological diversity, economic inequality and conflicts and disputes, we now have to act to protect the condition of our ocean. | | || The United Nations conference of the United Nations for the implementation of the goal of sustainable development 14: preserved and sustainably the oceans, seas and sea resources for sustainable development were convened from June 5th to 9th, 2017 in the United Nations headquarters. With World Oceans Day to support the implementation of the goal of sustainable development 14. The governments of Fiji and Sweden have the joint responsibility of the conference. The conference aims to be the player who will reverse the decline in the health of our ocean for people, planet and prosperity. It will be aligned with solutions with the commitment of all. The conference has caused the global awareness of ocean problems, strong ambitious results, including an intergovernmental political declaration "Our Ocean, our future: call to action", the summaries of the co-chairman of the co-chair of seven partnership dialogues and over 1400 volunteers Governments, the UN system, IGOS, the main groups and other interest groups -individually or in partnership -to drive the implementation of SDG 14 and related goals. The political explanation "Our Ocean, our future: Call to the action" was passed by Resolution A/71/312 by the General Assembly on July 6, 2017. ||| In paragraph 33 of the 2030 agenda for sustainable development, the Member States recognize that the Member States "depends on the sustainable management of the natural resources of our planet" and determine, oceans and seas, fresh water resources, mountains and Saving and using dry land and using the biological diversity, ecosystems and wild animals. The 2030 program recognizes that the eradication of poverty in all its forms and dimensions, including extreme poverty, is the largest global challenge and an essential requirement for sustainable development. ||| The first objective of sustainable development aims to "put an end to poverty in all its forms everywhere". Its seven associated targets aim, among other things, to eradicate extreme poverty for all people everywhere, reduce at least half of men, women and children of all ages living in poverty and implement systems of social protection Appropriate at the national level for all, including the floors, and by 2030, make substantial coverage of the poor and vulnerable ||| As recalled by the foreword report of the 2015 millennium development objectives report, during the Millennium Summit in September 2000, 189 countries unanimously adopted the Millennium Declaration, promising | || This commitment was translated by a framework inspiring with eight goals and, then, in large -scale practical stages that allowed people around the world to improve their lives and their future prospects. The MDGs have helped to raise more than a billion people to extreme poverty, to make breakthroughs against hunger, to allow more girls to go to school than ever before and to protect our planet. ||| Nevertheless, despite all the remarkable gains, the inequalities have persisted and the progress has been unequal. Consequently, the 2030 agenda for sustainable development and its set of sustainable development objectives have been committed, as indicated in the Declaration of the agenda, "to rely on the achievements of the millennial development objectives And try to attack their unfinished affairs ”. || | The theme of the 2017 high level political forum was ||| ", and he included SDG 1 as one of the ODD Focus ||| in" The Future We Wante the need to grant the greatest priority to the eradication of poverty within the United Nations Development Agenda , addressed the deep causes and the challenges of poverty through integrated, coordinated and consistent strategies at all levels. ||| In the context of the multi -year work program, adopted by the Sustainable Development Commission, held in March 1995 in Copenhagen. Being the biggest gathering of world leaders at the time, this event represented a crucial step and has committed to conquering poverty, the Goa L of full employment and the promotion of stable, safe and fair objectives of development. Chapter 2 is entirely devoted to the eradication of poverty with particular attention to the strategies to be adopted to obtain concrete results in this issue, to improve access to productive resources and infrastructure, to meet the fundamental human needs of all and improve social protection and reduce vulnerability. ||| Chapter 3 of the agenda describes poverty as "a complex multidimensional problem with origins in national and international fields". The agenda notes that no uniform solution can be found for the global application and identifies specific programs in the country to fight.

The ocean covers 70 percent of the Earth's surface, is the largest biosphere on the planet and hosts up to 80 percent of life in the world. It generates 50 % of the oxygen we need, absorbs 25 % of all carbon dioxide emissions and records 90 % of the additional heat generated by these emissions. It is not only the "lungs of the planet" but also the largest carbon sink - a vital regulatory solution against the effects of climate change. The unthinkable biodiversity is promoted and produces food, jobs, minerals and energy resources required for life on the planet to survive and thrive. There is many that we still do not know about the ocean, but there are many reasons why we need to manage sustainability - as defined in the objectives of the objective of sustainable growth 14: life under water. Science is clear - the ocean is facing unprecedented threats as a result of human activities. Its health and ability to maintain life will only deteriorate as the global population increases and human activities are increasing. If we want to address some of the most decisive issues of our time, such as climate change, food insecurity, diseases and pandemics, biodiversity reduction, economic inequality and even conflicts and conflicts, must be We are acting now to protect the condition of our ocean || The United Nations High Level Conference to support the implementation of the objective of sustainable development 14: Maintaining and sustainable use of oceans, seabirds and sea resources for sustainable development convened at the UN headquarters in New York by 5 Until June 9, 2017, they coincide with World Ocean Day to support the implementation of the objective of sustainable development 14. The governments of Fiji and Sweden have co-operating responsibilities of the Conference. The conference aims to be the change player who will reverse the decline in our ocean health for humans, the planet and prosperity. It will focus on solutions by all.The conference increased worldwide consciousness on ocean issues, produced strongly ambitious results, including an intergovernmental agreed policy of "Our Ocean, our future: Relationship and over 1400 voluntary commitments by governments, the United Nations system, IGO, large groups and other interested parties - individually or in partnership - to promote the application of SDG 14 and the relevant goals. The political statement "Our Ocean, Our Future: Appeal for Action" was adopted by the General Assembly on July 6, 2017 via voting A/71/312. "Social and Economic Development depends on the sustainable management of our planet's natural resources" and determines the preservation and use of sustainable oceans and seas, freshwater resources, as well as forests, mountains and dry territories and the protection of biodiversity, ecosystems and wildlife. "The goal of sustainable growth 14 aims to preserve and sustainable use of oceans, sea and sea resources for sustainable development. The conference was" the sustainable development of small island growing Corporate Relationships. "SIDS accelerates the ways of action, which took place between 19 73 and 1982. The contract was adopted in 1982, but came into force only in 1994 after the ratification of Guiana to the Treaty as 60th Country of Signs. The Convention describes the Rights and the responsibilities of nations in terms of the use of the world's oceans, setting guidelines for businesses, the environment Lon and the management of marine natural resources.

Respect and promotion of human rights violations have no place in our supply chains. Our values ​​are rooted in respect, including respect for human rights of each person working for or with us. Our commitments to respect and promote human rights p. Evaluate and process human rights impacts in our commercial activities p. Provide effective grievance mechanisms to employees and stakeholders for whom this is important, the last years have seen increased attention to business responsibility to respect human rights in their activities and trade relations. Consumers want to know more and more human rights in the supply chains of the products they buy and there is greater interest in investors and regulators in this area. We believe that the maintenance of human rights of people who work for or with us are essential to make our business activities and provide more stable and sustainable resilient chains. Our contribution, although our size and our scale allow us to have an influence, we know that the sector and sustainable change require collaboration with others. We work with expert organizations such as the Danish Institute for Human Rights at the Fair Labor Association The Issara Issara Issara Issara Issara Instary Trust and Profinest Institute to make sure to understand the challenges and continually refine our approach to implement actions that have a real impact. With DIHR, we have identified our most salient human rights problems which have the greatest risk of negative impact on people within our activities. Specific action plans tackle these questions ensuring that human rights are respected and promoted in our commercial activities. In recent years, we have joined human rights work in our activities and policies. This has been extended to the adoption of our new care audit protocol. We have examined its content on the basis of the lessons learned in recent years within the framework of our reasonable human rights diligence program and in particular through human rights impact assessments . As we are progressing on our human rights journey, we will also focus on our supply chain in the years to come, because it is clearly there that the most salient questions of the rights of Man, for example children and forced work can be found. All our employees worldwide will receive our new human rights training program for key issues. We also develop a governance structure in all markets to further explore human rights issues.

In this article, two parks, Qeytariyeh Park and Niyavaran Park were studies in the north of Tehran, Iran, according to SDG. The study was designed specifically around objective 11 and the application of sustainable development in cities. After a research literature review, the parks were examined to retrace their success as a public space from the ODD point of view. Qualitative methods have been used to study field observations and personal interviews with daily visitors to random selected parks with a small control over the demography of sex and age. The main objective of the article is to note how successful these parks are based on sustainable development standards and, in the end, there are solutions proposed to resolve the weakness of these case studies.

Recognizing the need to respond to washing challenges in high -income nations, organizers at the University of California Merced, University of Colorado Boulder, University of North Carolina in Chapel Hill. 'The purpose of the session was to summon a network of researchers, professionals, community representatives and policy formulators focused on washing high -income contexts to identify areas of shared experience, challenges and necessity. The results below summarize the main topics and priorities, as described by the session participants. Quotations are provided to refer the reader to additional scholarships on each topic that emerged during the session, but are not intended to indicate that the results are the result of a systematic review of the authors' literature. The subsequent discussion section summarizes the results of the session in recommendations and action steps for future research, policies and practices. Thus, this practical article aims to inform high country governments, academics, water professionals and wastewater, and the widest washing community about priorities and future collaborations needed to achieve universal washing and equitable coverage in high -income countries.

Expanded Access Program Gileads Expanded Access Program Access to our research drugs that may be an appropriate option when approved therapies or clinical trials are not available to some people with serious or life exchange conditions. Fast access to our extreme climate events program, such as hurricanes and oods, can threaten health systems and interrupt access to care. Annual report on sustainability water stewardship because it imports access to safe water is a fundamental human right. Water is essential for the good -to be in our communities and the environment and is necessary for the founding facilities of mines and recovery projects. Many of our operations are in arid environments, where competition for water supply is significant. Although we usually have western water for our Indonesian operations, the PTFI Highlands area receives considerable precipitation that makes excess water management supplies the main challenge. The unique circumstances of each of our operations reinforce the critical importance of managing the impacts of our activities on water availability and quality, optimizing our use of water and respecting other people's rights. Our Freeport approach believes that water stewardship and Écator means maximizing our ecience of water use so that we can minimize our use of new freshwater. This includes changing our water supply to more sustainable sources, minimizing the negative impacts of our quality operations and water availability in a local watershed and supporting the development of access to previously unknown or unknown water resources. . In addition to focusing on our own water -related risk risks around our operations, water stewardship also means that we are focused on promoting long -term water safety for all. We recognize the importance of working in collaboration with our stakeholders to ensure access to water in a social and environmentally responsible manner and dedicated ourselves to improving our water programs over time. POLICY PROGRAMS GLOORY OUR OBJECT is to identify the management and mitigation of our current and future water -related risks to ensure the necessary water resources to support our long -term operations, equitly supporting the rights and the good -to bear of our partners and ecosystems of Local community. Our global goals of the water management program are as follows to improve the efficiency of water use in our processes, minimizing the use of freshwater in our operations, reduces our water footprint, transition to renewable water sources or recycled and monitor our impact on surrounding communities and environment, continually reviewing water supplies. and future requirements. We support and are in the process of implementing the ICMM water position declaration, which describes our commitment to public reports and responsible water use, including strong and transparent water governance, water management and water collaboration to achieve the Responsible and sustainable use of water. The climate by which imports climate change represents considerable challenges close and long term for society. Mining is intensive in energy and generates significant greenhouse gas emissions that contribute to climate change. However, copper and molybdenum, we produce an essential role in global decarbonization. It is a critical component in technologies that will be implemented in a highly electrified and low carbon economy, including solar and wind energy and electric vehicles. These technologies are fundamental to support the global energy transition needed to meet the goals of Paris agreements. Our approach as one of the largest copper producers in the world, we understand our critical role in low carbon energy transition. We dedicate to the global economy copper produced responsibly, including operating in a way that manages and mitigates our GHG emissions and other climate -reached risks and impacts. Our climate strategy is based on three pillars of resilience and contribution. Reduction We strive to reduce management and mitigate our GHG emissions whenever possible. We built our initial public target to reduce our intensity of GHG emissions in the Americas by tonne from copper cathode with an additional commitment to reduce the intensity of GHE emissions in Indonesia by ton of copper resolution to be paid to reach both of our base line. We also plan to develop two additional gee emissions reduction goals for our primary molybdenum locations and another for the copper Atlantic. Resilience We strive to improve our resilience to physical and transitional risks associated with climate change for our operations, our host communities and our stakeholders. This includes working proactively to analyze and prepare for an increase in extreme water stress and other impacts on climate change, as well as support our host communities and respond to market demands and early regulatory. Contribution we strive to be a positive contributor beyond our operational limits, producing copper and molybdenum responsibility that will support the technologies necessary to allow the energy transition. This includes collaborating with partners in our value chain and industry associations to identify weather solutions that will support the transition to a low carbon economy and finally achieve the goals of the Paris Agreement.

In addition to its financial education programs, the Rosiffeisen Bank S.A. In Romania organized the Rosiffisen Communities on -line contest for the tenth time. Non -governmental non -governmental organizations and public institutions and educational institutions are invited to apply for scholarships. In all eleven donations endowed, a total of eleven educational projects were granted. The purpose of this project is to improve the level of education and therefore the quality of life of people living in Romania. The educational projects were submitted to which they were eligible and received scholarships, including a sustainability course for secondary schools in Cluj and a professional workshop for adolescents living in Tru Jiu. The Stepic CEE charity, fueled by the Raiffeisen Bank International, founded by the ex -CEO of the RBI, Herbert Stepic, the Stepic CEE Charity Institution supports young and women children in central and eastern Europe. The support form is adjusted to reeite the respective requirements focused on education. Thanks to its deep local roots, its pragmatic approach and the active support of RBI network banks, the charity institution offers people the perspective of an independent life away from poverty. Education is the key. All charity projects are carried out in cooperation with local or international partner organizations renowned and managed by RBI volunteer officials in Vienna as part of the corporate volunteering program from and in their places in Central and Eastern Europe. This serves to minimize administrative costs with all financial contributions going directly to the projects. The importance of charity work is even more evident in times of crisis. The schools and day care centers operated by the charity were closed during the coronavirus blockade, see also the page. Even a temporary interruption in education can have a negative impact on the significant long term on child life. It is the girls who suffer the most, as they are pushed back to the traditional roles they need support to break free. Without the work of the institution of charity, the children he cares would return to a circle of poverty that is usually accompanied by negligence and abuse. Working in close contact with children and parents the charity ensures that children are well cared for, thus reducing the existential pressure that weighs a lot in many families. Both are connected instrumentally: without suitable foods, athletic activities are impossible, unattainable elite performance and impractical fan. Thus, the central objective of the “zero hunger” of the sustainable development objective 2 is highly relevant to the sport. Sports organizations usually deal with hunger via charity. Although these well-meaning efforts meet the immediate need, they do not address the systemic causes of hunger and food insecurity. As a result, they can involuntarily allow hunger to persist. Sports organizations that work for SDG 2 should reorient their efforts to reinforce political law and action at the community level. Based on food citizenship for food security structure, the authors present various recommendations to use their financial resources, public profiles and political influence to amplify the work of food justice activists seeking structural changes and community empowerment, finally replacing hunger for equity.

The annual report on climate of sustainability because it matters Freeport acknowledges that climate change represents considerable and long -term challenges for society and our own operational performance. Mining is intensive in energy and generates significant greenhouse gas emissions that contribute to climate change. However, copper plays an essential role in the technologies needed to develop and offer low carbon energy, including solar and energy ecient technologies, which are critical to support the global energy transition to meet the Paris Agreement on climate change . Our approach as one of the world's largest copper producers, Freeport, understands its critical role in the transition of low carbon energy. We are still dedicated to providing the global economy produced with copper responsibility and operates in a way that manages and mitigates our GHG emissions and other weather risks. We published our inaugural climate report has set our GHG emissions reduction target to the Americas and committed to aligning our climate strategy and disclosures related to force recommendations -TCFD Comefd Financial Disclosure in the coming years. We also formalize our strategy of climate change, founded on the resilience and contribution of three pillars. Reduction we strive to manage mitigate and reduce our gee emissions whenever possible. As a first step, we have established our initial public goal to reduce our Gee emissions in the Americas by ton of copper cathode in our base line. Resilience We strive to improve our resilience to physical and transitional risks associated with climate change for our operations, our host communities and our stakeholders. This includes working proactively to analyze and prepare for extreme water stress and other impacts of climate change. Contribution that we strive to be a positive contributor beyond our operational limits, producing copper and molybdenum responsibility to the energy transition. This includes collaborating with partners in our value chain with the ultimate goal of achieving the objectives of the Paris Agreement. To learn more about our climate approach, including our strategy, read our inaugural climate report available on our website. We will also publish our climate report later this year. The copper produced responsibly is necessary for the technologies necessary to develop and activate the energy transition. RA International Sustainability Right Rights Rights Report Employee Survee in Octobre we conducted a survey on Largescale employees to help map the current state and identify any work topics that require greater focused attention. The survey included questions about the awareness of political knowledge about the violations of policies and how much employees are found at ease in reporting discrimination and harassment. All the permanent Ras staff was asked to complete the survey that could do anonymously online. Our staff welcomed the possibility of providing feedback and shared many precious intuitions that we are now using as a basis for our future sustainability of human resources and conformity efforts. The results of the survey showed that RA employees generally include the policies of our companies well and the majority believes that they have had adequate opportunities to ask questions about them. However, it has become clear that not everyone knows how to report a concern or a violation or what is classified as a violation of politics and what is not. This means that we must communicate more clearly on our reporting processes. It could also explain why we received very few reports that required actions through our independent informants channel. Therefore we are planning further training on the RA reporting process and the use of our informants channel. The survey also indicated that some of our employees experience discrimination and harassment in the workplace despite our best efforts and intentions. Now we are taking actions to remedy this situation starting from a study to verify the number of people affected and deepen our understanding of the situation. The fact that the survey data are filtered by position means that we can direct our efforts to deal with the challenges faced by specific groups in specific places. From now on, the employees' polls will be conducted every year to measure progress over time. For our survey we decided to invest in a custom employee survey tool created by external specialists. The new tool will provide us with more detailed data to work with and will therefore provide a more solid base on which to build corrective measures.

Rusta Sustainability Financial Report Ethics Good Business Ethics Ness Ethics Politics. Rusta strives to act fairly and transparently through the different levels of our supply chain. The approach of zerotolerance Rusta has a policy of zerotolerance towards any form of corruption or corruption. Colleagues are obliged and encouraged to report any undue or inappropriate interaction between them their colleagues and third parties to their manager. In addition, we regularly organize training sessions on the subject of corruption and corruption in our supply offices in China in Sweden and Vietnam. Denunciation policy Our denunciation policy is incorporated into our basic code of external stakeholders to use the denunciation function if they observe or suspect any conduct indicating a corrupt behavior compared to our suppliers.

Tailings management why it is important that tailings and identifier management is fundamental for mining to safely protect people and the environment and maintain the social license to operate. The tailings are natural or by -products rock particles of Nelly Ground natural that remain after economically valuable minerals have been prosecuted and extracted from the mining mineral. In general, tailings are transported from processing facilities to management and storage facilities. We recognize that the possible failure of tailings facilities and other reservoirs in any of our mining operations could cause severe properties and in some cases catastrophic and environmental damage, as well as the loss of lives. Our approach to the health and safety of our communities for the reception of the workforce and the environment are fundamental for our extensive program and tailings management approach. Our goal is to have zero catastrophic failures and zero unplanned downloads of any of our tailings facilities. Freeport has comprehensive measures to ensure that our facilities are designed operated and monitored to minimize the risk for employees of neighboring host communities and the environment. These measures include a technological monitoring of substantial internal and external engineering, including the local responsibility for remote sensing and supervision of the third corporate and independent party. Our safeguards are generally within four categories that include good engineering practices and safe designs of rigorous adhesion to construction and operational parameters through monitoring and the use of technology supervision and adherence to practices based on continuous improvement and Learning past experiences, including industry failures and best practices. The safeguards are implemented identifier through the promotion of open and continuous communication throughout the organization and action at all levels. We continue to focus on the safe execution of our tailings management systems through interdisciplinary collaborations in our corporate sites and OCE. We organize workshops information sessions and training for our tailings engineers. These events support our teams with the exchange of knowledge in all places and provide opportunities to collaborate and develop relationships throughout the organization.

The goal of sustainable development is related to hunger ending, achieving food safety and improving nutrition and promoting sustainable agriculture. The SDGs report that only a few political indicators, and in particular SDG2, are largely deprived of political estimates to end hunger and achieve food security. The Nobel Prize -winning Amartya Sen has famously observed the absence of famine in democracies, suggesting that a democratic system provides controls and balances that prevent hunger. His observation has caused further discussion and has caused empirical studies in recent years. In addition to the SEN case, this essay examines other political actors that would explain the vulnerability to hunger and must be more explicitly treated in SDG 2 and similar initiatives. Taking the case of pastors in the AFAR area of ​​Ethiopia, this research is investigating selected political decisive vulnerability factors in hunger. The war of Eritrea-Ethiopia and the consequent closure of the border had a harmful impact on the livelihood of pastors in long-term pastors were deprived of a market and a reliable source of income. In addition, the long -term shepherd were sidelined by the informal salt area on which they were based. The state facilitated this expropriation, leaving the shepherds even more vulnerable to famine. I argue that political estimates are vital to the successful end of hunger and achieve food security. The essay uses a quality case design design and is based on a doctoral thesis.

The ocean covers 70 percent of the earth's surface, is the largest biosphere on the planet and home up to 80 % of the whole life in the world. It generates 50 percent of oxygen we need, absorbs 25 percent of all carbon dioxide emissions and captures 90 percent of the additional heat generated by these emissions. They are not only "the lungs of the planet", but also its largest carbon sink - a vital pad against the impact of climate change. And thrive. There is much that we do not yet know about the ocean, but there are many reasons why we must manage it sustainability - as indicated in the objectives of the objective of sustainable development 14: life under water. The political declaration "Our Ocean, our future: invitation to action" was adopted by the General Assembly on 6 July 2017 through resolution A/71/312. "Social and economic development depends on the sustainable management of the natural resources of our planet" and determines to preserve and use oceans and seas in a sustainable way, freshwater resources, as well as forests, mountains and dry lands and to protect biodiversity, Ecosystems and wildlife ". SDG1 presents the world community with an important but extremely difficult goal. When discussing the possibility of tourism in SDG1 to "end poverty in all forms of everywhere", it must be considered the multidimensional nature of poverty instead of focusing solely on economic deprivation. In particular, we must shift the focus beyond how tourism can promote economic growth, provide jobs and income, to examine the socio -political aspects of poverty and the way in which structural inequalities interfere with development of people. The contradictions involved in the poor, poor locations, with bad labor rights, put smiling faces to serve rich visitors to the former colonial forces and clean their caresses should not be overlooked if we are really interested in questioning World tourism and making it fairest and more viable in the future. So, if governments and players in industry tourism want to do more than to pay the lips on SDG1, they should make some significant changes in the way they work. This article will draw inspiration from tourism businesses in Fiji facing SDG1 and related goals and discuss how to contribute to long -term sustainable development.

Analysis of existing monitoring activities shows that the largest challenges that cause data gaps are associated with the novelty of most indicators and their complexity. There are no conceptual problems regarding the methodologies of the indicator, but the challenging conditions that complicate data collection. A key element to increase data availability in the coming years is national training, as national data create the basis for monitoring global indicators. In addition, the extent of data sources can be expanded, for example by aligning national and regional initiatives with global objectives, allowing common monitoring efforts and thus reducing the load of reports from countries. In this context, protocol in water and health can potentially increase data availability in the Pan-European region. Comparison of SDG 6 indicators and the current protocol report model indicates that there are already aspects that require very similar data. However, small modifications can improve these overlaps and facilitate the common use of the national monitoring capacity and collected data. Comparing the country's current reports and the latest JMP progress reports suggest that various parts of the protocol do not completely exploit this potential.

Sport and food can be powerful health, well-being and cohesion agents of the community. However, as both climbed, their goals and encouraging impacts have changed. Both are connected instrumentally: without suitable foods, athletic activities are impossible, unattainable elite performance and impractical fan. Thus, the central objective of the “zero hunger” of the sustainable development objective 2 is highly relevant to the sport. Sports organizations usually deal with hunger via charity. Although these well-meaning efforts meet the immediate need, they do not address the systemic causes of hunger and food insecurity. As a result, they can involuntarily allow hunger to persist. Sports organizations that work for SDG 2 should reorient their efforts to reinforce political law and action at the community level. Based on food citizenship for food security structure, the authors present various recommendations to use their financial resources, public profiles and political influence to amplify the work of food justice activists seeking structural changes and community empowerment, finally replacing hunger for equity.

The objective of sustainable development 10, reducing inequality in countries and countries, was among the last of the OSS to add. SDG 10 was largely a reaction to the growing attention that was paid to the gross disparity of the wealth observed all over the world and to the political reciprocity to those disparities. Although it can be understood as a request for redistribution of wealth globally, it is unlikely that large -scale redistribution through taxation or other means is politically feasible as a solution to inequality soon. It is more plausibly interpreted as a request for a reduction in inequalities, those factors that prevent people and states from having a fair shot upon reaching prosperity and development. Within the national states, we can see this as a request for an approach based on the rights to development - an approach that tries to give people skills to be successful by removing also political and social factors, such as discrimination and repression, who prevent them from reaching their potential. Internationally, it is linked to the concept of development right, which places assistance obligations on states developed to help the poorest ones. International institutions such as the World Bank and the United Nations have the mandate to promote these rights and can act as intermediate institutions, lending credibility to this push for the recognition of development rights. The objectives established by 10 SDG are more vague and aspiration than those of most of the other SDGs, but the end of the loyal inequalities of wealth could be seen as a basic problem that makes many other SDG possible. As such, SDG 10 requires certain tasks to those parts that can make it reality.

Access to energy in the world is critical today. Energy is a key factor in achieving other SDGs, including SDG7. However, identifying and evaluating the relationship between different energy scenarios to achieve SDG 7 and other SDGs have not yet done. This document seeks to fill this gap by exploring how elderly energy can help achieve SDG 7 and other SDGs. The Web of Science, Sciencedirect and Scopus databases were used for a systematic review. A total finish of 25 of 249 documents was filled from 2015 to December 2020 through the criteria for inclusion and exclusion. This review includes six elderly energy, which are primarily associated with the achievement of SDG 7 and other SDGs: Modern Energy 20% and other SDGs. The results of this systematic review provide a sense of direction for future researchers for future studies in this area.
