The ocean covers 70 percent of the land surface, is the largest biosphere on the planet and the home of up to 80 percent of a lifetime in the world. It generates 50 percent of the oxygen we need, absorbs 25 percent of all carbon dioxide emissions and captures 90 percent of the additional heat generated from these emissions. It is not just about 'the lungs of the planet', but also its largest carbon sink, a vital cushion against the impacts of climate change. Nourishes unimaginable biodiversity and produces food, jobs, mineral and energy resources necessary for life on the planet to survive and prosper. There is much that we do not know about the ocean, but there are many reasons why we need to administer its sustainability, as established in the objectives of the Sustainable Development Objective 14: Life under water. Science is clear: the ocean is to face unprecedented threats as a result of human activities. Their health and ability to maintain life will only worsen as the world's population grows and human activities increase. If we want to address some of the most defining problems of our time, such as climate change, food insecurity, diseases and pandemics, the decrease in biodiversity, economic inequality and even conflicts and struggles, we must now act to protect The state of our ocean. || The United Nations Conference of High Level to support the implementation of the Sustainable Development Objective 14: conserve and sustainably use the oceans, seas and marine resources for sustainable development, it was convened at the United Nations headquarters in New York from June 5 to 9, 2017, coinciding with World Ocean Day, to support the implementation of the Sustainable Development Objective 14. The governments of Fiji and Sweden have the responsibilities of co-elans of the conference. The conference aims to be the change of play that will reverse the decline in the health of our ocean for people, planet and prosperity. It will focus on solutions with everyone's commitment. The conference increased the global awareness of oceanic issues, produced strong ambitious results, including an intergovernmental political declaration "our ocean, our future: called to action", the summaries of the co -chants of seven association dialogues, and more than 1400 voluntary commitments Of the governments, the UN system, the IGO, the main groups and other stakeholders, individually or in association, to advance in the implementation of the SDG 14 and the related objectives. The political declaration "Our Ocean, our future: called Action" was adopted by the General Assembly on July 6, 2017 through Resolution A/71/312. ||| In paragraph 33 of the 2030 Agenda for sustainable development, Member States recognize that "social and economic development depends on the sustainable management of the natural resources of our planet" and determines to conserve and use in a sustainable way and seas, resources, resources, resources of fresh water, as well as forests, mountains and dry lands and protect biodiversity, ecosystems and wildlife. "The objective of sustainable development 14 aims to conserve and use the oceans, seas and marine resources for development sustainably sustainable. The conference was "the sustainable development of the states in development of the small islands through genuine and lasting associations." The SMSL accelerated the action modalities, held between 19 years 73 and 1982. The convention was adopted in 1982, but it entered into force only in 1994 after the ratification of Guyana to the treaty as 60º signatory country. The Convention describes the rights and responsibility Ades of the nations regarding their use of the oceans of the world, establishing guidelines for companies, the environment and the management of marine natural resources.

As a Muslim majority, Bangladesh has not yet incorporated the Islamic tools of poverty eradication such as Zakah and Waqf in the policies and strategies of eradication of national poverty, although WAQF resources raise enormous potential to achieve the development objective Sustainable 1 with the objective of "ending the population." In general, WAQF resources are spent privately to establish and administer different religious institutions where its diversified uses to get the poor out of poverty ruin when managing resources receive less attention. Most WAQF properties are not illegally occupied, underutilized or not used to comply with social welfare sustainably due to policy deficiency and poor administrative agreement. This document aims to find the way in which the WAQF resource can be a powerful tool to reach SDG-1. It provides a seven-time strategic model to mobilize WAQF resources under the seven SDG-1 objectives and suggestions to revitalize WAQF to achieve broader social welfare in Bangladesh.

The livelihood of more than 30 percent of the total population in India in nine maritime states and four union areas depends on the various ecosystem services offered by coastal and sea systems. Due to the foreign exchange, marine fishing contributes significantly to the Indian economy from the export of seafood, which corresponds to almost 5 percent of the entire export and 20 percent of agro export. Recently, anthropogenic pressure is performing challenges in the marine environment due to extensive marine fishing. Marine anthropogeomorphology, which can change the natural settings of the continental shelf dominant, is often not examined in detail from the perspective of sustainable catch. For example, the use of the different fishing lengths can damage the sea floor apart from the capture of young people and not targeted fish. The soil, which drags through mechanized craft as part of the sea fishing, affects the geomorphology of the continental shelf and continental slope by displacing boulders, interrupting the structure of the sediment column, resonating and shaping deep holes on the mud area. Occasionally, the abandoned fisheries/gears on the sea floor are also responsible for the geomorphological damage to the sea floor and the death of several marine Benthischer Flora and Fauna, a phenomenon that is described as "ghost fish". In addition, the knot agency, which has been distributed since 1999, is illegal, not reported and unregulated with the help of remote-tensioned data sets with sea surface temperature and chlorophyll-A to reduce uncertainty during the sea fishing. The PFZ consultant can help promote environmentally friendly fish by shortening the search time and thus ensuring minimal damage to the sea environment.

Since Kenya endeavors to maintain the dynamics in his race for sustainable development by 2030, his situation in nutritional certainty remains precarious. If Kenya should not achieve hunger by 2030, efforts must be required to scale the profits achieved. Currently, the effects of climate socket, covid-19, grasshopper invasion and an economy that does not grow as expected, continue to worsen nutritional uncertainty. While it has achieved the long-term rainfall over the years, these profits are lost due to an economy that fluctuates and due to the violence after the 2007/2008 election and now even more because of Covid 19. This weak economy works a negative approach to access, not only for food, but also availability. It is estimated that by the end of this year many Kenyans will be unsure of food that need humanitarian aid. While the majority of Kenyans have access to food, it still cannot fulfill the recommended rations. Many Kenyans have access to foods that are affordable, which makes less and less nutrition. Although Kenya is currently an income industry with a lower mean, it still has an estimated 238,000 in the emergency phase. Dry and semi-arid countries have the highest food uncertainty. The change in climate patterns has led to poor performance of the short rains. Climate change has a negative impact on the already fragile situation of nutritional security. The increasing level of food uncertainty threatens to negate profits in Kenya's progress towards zero hunger. While the challenges continue to exist, the United Nations' World Food Program works together with the Kenya government to improve efforts to build up a sustainable food system that will ensure sustainability in food and nutritional security in Kenya. Therefore, this study tries to evaluate the role of WFP when reaching SDG 2 in Kenya. The study was based on primary and secondary data.

The lack of national data on water-related ecosystems is a great challenge to achieve the objective of sustainable development, Sentinel-1 and SRTM data for Jamaica, Peru and Senegal. Using Landsat 8 and Sentinel 2a images, total suspended solids and chlorophyll-A are assigned over time for a select number of large bodies of surface water in Peru, Senegal and Zambia. All eo data sets used are global coverage and are publicly available at no cost. The temporary consistency and the long time series of many of the data sets allow replicability over time, which makes the report of the changes in basal values ​​consistent and systematic. We find that statistical comparisons between different surface water data can help provide a certain degree of confidence for countries during their validation process and highlight the need for precision evaluations when land change data is used based on EO for ODS reports. We also propose the concern that EO data in the context of the ODS 6.6.1 reports may be more challenging for some countries, such as small island nations, than others used to evaluate the scope of ecosystems related to water due to scale limitations and climate variability. The validation promoted by the country of EO data products remains a priority to ensure successful data integration in support of the SDG 6.6.1 Reports indicator. Studies from several countries such as this can be valuable tools to help guide the evolution of ODS monitoring methodologies and provide a useful resource for countries that report water -related ecosystems. EO data analysis and statistical methods used in this study can easily be replicated for the validation of EO data products promoted by the country in the future.

SDG1 presents the global community an important but very difficult objective. When you discuss the potential of tourism to contribute to SDG1 to "put an end to poverty in all its forms everywhere", the multidimensional nature of poverty must be considered rather than focusing solely on economic deprivation. More specifically, we must move attention beyond the way tourism can promote economic growth, provide jobs and income, to taking into account the socio-political aspects of poverty and the way in which structural inequalities hinder people's development. The contradictions involved in the poor, in poor places, with mediocre labor rights, putting smiling faces to serve as rich guests of former colonial powers and to clean their messages, should not be overlooked if We are really interested in questioning the negative aspects of the negative aspects of the negative aspects of the negative aspects of the negative aspects of world tourism and making it more equitable and lasting in the future. Thus, if governments and players in the tourism industry wish to do more than pay lip services to SDG1, they will have to make important changes to the way they work. This article will be inspired by tourist companies in Fiji which are aimed at EDG1 and related objectives, and discuss how they have the potential to contribute to sustainable development in the longer term.

If you discuss the potential of tourism, to contribute to SDG1 in order to "end poverty in all its forms everywhere", the multi -dimensional nature of poverty must be taken into account rather than concentrating on economic deprivation. In particular, we have to focus on the development of sociopolitical aspects of poverty and, like structural inequalities that hinder people's development, the development of people and how structural inequalities can affect people's development. The contradictions associated with poor people, in poor places, with poor labor rights, smiled faces to serve rich guests of former colonial powers and to clean up their disorder if we are really interested in the negative aspects of To question global tourism and in the future more fairer and sustainable. If the players of the governments and the tourism industry want to pay more than just lip service for SDG1, they have to make some significant changes to the way they work. This article will be inspired by tourism companies in Fiji who deal with SDG1 and related goals and discuss how they have the potential to contribute to a long -term sustainable development.

We have developed a conceptual framework connecting key indicators of the progression of SDG 1 to the impact of tuberculosis via well described risk factor tracks and filled them with data from the SDG data frame and the database WHO tuberculosis for 192 countries. The correlations and mediation analyzes have informed the strength of the association between the SDG 1 sub -i-subi and the incidence of tuberculosis, which leads to a simplified framework for modeling. The simplified framework has linked key indicators for the ODD 1 directly to the impact of tuberculosis. We applied an exponential disintegration model based on linear associations between the SDG 1 indicators and the incidence of tuberculosis to estimate the incidence of tuberculosis in 2035.

Banks have banking carboneutral operations in climate and environmental impacts constitute a great challenge to our society and Spar Nord is interested and is interested and consponsures to face this challenge. Consequently, Spar Nord is a signatory to the sustainable development goals, a Global Compact SDGs, which forms the basis for our efforts to reduce our negative carbon footprint. In its current strategy plan, Spar Nord has defined the ambition to make the bank's carbon neutral for a period of time. Through reduction and compensation measures, we perform the objective of climateneutrality in the scope and at the end of. Mangrove trees that provide climate compensation that Spar Nord has chosen to compensate for the part of bank greenhouse gas emissions that we are not yet able to reduce a total of. tcoe. We do this by buying climate credits at the Thor Heyerdahl climate park, which will contribute to the planting of mangrove forests in Myanmar. We decided to support this project because mangrove trees absorb up to five times more strain than other trees and store strain directly on the ground. Also, as mangrove trees are easy to plant and grow rapidly, a major effect is achieved relatively quickly. The project also contributes to creating jobs and building a circular society, ensuring better living conditions for the local population. Study findings show that providing access to sustainable energy in LDCs to serve SDG7 by 2030 can be a challenge due to limited access to technology, infrastructure and finance. The United Nations Agenda of 2030 has framed the objective of sustainable development 9 about eight objectives outlined in A/Res/71/313 resolution. The purpose of this chapter is that the conferences, without a lot of previous knowledge on SDG9, include the fundamental concepts involved in each of the eight objectives. Multiple discussion points emerge when they reflect on the nature of these concepts and others emerge when they reflect on them in the sector settings. The first section of this chapter covers issues relating to resilient infrastructure. The resilient infrastructure is related to the objectives 9.1, 9.4 and 9.a. This concept must face extreme natural events potentially associated with global warming and climate change. The second section focuses on the importance of technological innovation in the context of objectives 9.5 and 9.B. In a corporate sector, innovation allows you to strengthen industrial competitiveness and increase business sustainability. The third concept treated in this chapter is the technology of information and communication which is a key to understanding the target 9.c. Last but not least, two essential ideas are discussed: industrialization and inclusive and sustainable financial services, which are fundamental elements in the 9.2 lens and the target 9.3. In a sense, it is possible to conclude that both concepts integrate all previous conceptions.

This study is an endeavor to examine the causes of increasing inequality in India at a subnational level and thus to achieve political effects in order to achieve goals under SDG 10 The disaggregated level and the understanding of its causes are of essential importance for the well -founded guideline report. Since the beginning of the economic reform in 1991, there has been an increasing income in India. Due to the opening of the economy, the growth rates in the states that have the production of the states have increased quickly after 1993. This seems to expand the income gap. So far, however, only a few studies have tried to analyze the causes of increasing inequalities in Indian countries. This study, which analyzes data from 18 most important Indian states, shows that structural transformations and trade liberalization cause inequality for the increase in Indian countries in the period after the reform. On the other hand, the evidence of the infrastructure that leads to an increase in inequality must be treated with caution due to the presence of outliers. It is assumed that these results have important political effects.

Annual report on sustainability -tailings stewardship Why is it of importance for the health and security of our host communities and the environment of extensive tailing management programs of fundamental importance. Tailings are the natural natural stone particles or by -products that were processed according to the economically valuable minerals and taken from the mined ore. As a rule, our tailings include an openings of natural rock particles that are transported from processing systems to management and storage facilities. We recognize that failure of tailing facilities and other pollution can cause severe property and environmental damage as well as loss of life in some cases. Our FREPORT approach has extensive measures to ensure that our facilities are operated and monitored to minimize the risk of neighboring employees and the environment. We have a strong commitment from our board of directors and the managing director of providing the necessary nancial and technical resources in order to maintain the safety of our facilities and the integrity of our tailing management systems, whereby the focus is on continuous improvements. Our Tailing Management and Stewardship program, which enlarges external engineers from record and regular supervision by independent Tailing Tailing Review Boards and Stewardship teams, adheres to applicable regulations and various national and international guidelines. The program also corresponds to the Tailing Governance framework to prevent the catastrophic failure of our Tailings storage facilities assumed by ICMM in December. In as members of ICMM, we have supported and committed the development of the development of the new global industrial standard for Tailing Management The Tailings Standard. The tailing standard was developed by an independent multi -tower holder process, which was coconved by the principles of the United Nations environmental program for responsible investments and ICMM after the collapse of the tragic tailing facility in Brumadinho Brazil collided. Thanks to our membership in ICMM, Freeport played an active leadership role and made constructive contributions in the development of tailing standard. Formally introduced in August The Tailing Standard is the first global standard for tailing management that can be applied to existing and future tailing facilities. The Tailings standard was integrated into ICMMS existing membership obligations, and ICMM members have agreed that all tailings with extreme or very high potential consequence ratings within three years within three years within VA years the conformity with the tailing standard must prove August. Freeport is currently promoting internal plans to fulfill this engagement. A sub -group of the ICMM working group for the ICMM Tailings also led to Freeport to develop a guide to determining and recommending best practice for the practical implementation of tailing.

Avoiding, reducing and reversing land degradation and the restoration of degraded land is an urgent priority for the protection of biodiversity and ecosystem services that are vital to life on Earth. In order to stop and reversing current trends in land downgrading, there is an immediate need to strengthen national capabilities to carry out quantitative evaluations and mapping their degraded territories, as required by the objectives of sustainable development. In response to this issue, this document presents an initial overview of an innovative approach to monitoring land downgrading on the national scale according to SDG15.3.3 using Landsat observations using a data cube, but further work is required to improve calculation of the three subcutaneous.

Agenda 2030 follows a universal approach and identifies countries in the global south and in the global north, which have to turn towards sustainability. Therefore, countries of the global north like Germany have signed the commitment to implement the goals for sustainable development. This article aims to analyze how global goals that deal with urban developments are contextualized at the national level. Our results show that only some of the original goals and indicators for SDG 11 are used in German context. Therefore, important adjustments were made according to the most important sustainability problems for Germany. In addition, our results show that the current contextualization of SDG 11 and sustainable urban development in Germany continues and further changes and obligations must be made.

Access to safe water is a fundamental human right and it is essential to the well-being of communities and the environment. The stewardship of water why it is important that access to safe water is a fundamental human right and it is essential to the well-being of communities and the environment. It is also necessary for mines transformation facilities and restoration projects. The effective management of water resources can reduce the impact of mining activities on availability and water quality while respecting the rights of others. Our approach water is essential to our work and vital at the long -term sustainability of the company and our host communities. We cannot operate without water and freeport includes the critical importance of the management of the impacts of our activities on the availability and quality of water and respect for the rights of our reception communities and our Aboriginal neighbors . The Freeports Water Management Program focuses on the maximization of our water use consumption in our operations so that we can minimize our use of new freshwater from the natural environment. We also focus on moving our water supplies to more sustainable recycled sources, renewable reused and lower quality sources minimizing the negative impacts of our operations on the quality and availability of water in local watersheds and support The development of access to unlivable or unknown water resources. In addition to focusing on our own risk -related supply risks surrounding our operations, the stewardship of water also means that we focus on promoting long -term water safety for all. We recognize the importance of working in collaboration with our stakeholders to guarantee access to water in a social and environmentally friendly manner and we are committed to continuously improving our water programs over time. The worldwide nature of our operations requires a tailor -made site relevant approach to our water strategy. Many of our operations are in arid environments where there is significant competition for water. Conversely, our colorado and Indonesia operations present a different challenge receiving so much precipitation that a considerable EORT consists in managing the excess of water supply.

This article begins with the promotion of the opportunities of the objectives of sustainable growth, which guided international anti -poverty action between 2000 and 2015. Effective environmental administration is considered essential to promote the goals for sustainable development. However, environmental dimensions have no specific reference about the SDG 16 targets and indicators. When achieving SDG 16 - the realization of peace, justice and strong institution, earned polyentric environmental administration, in which several players are involved on a very yardstick. This study shows the potential of a polycentric approach to environmental administration in the achievement of SDG 16 using case studies of forest, water sheath and cross-border Buschland and soul management in Southeast Asia and East Africa, namely Vietnam, Indonesia and Kenia-Somalia Crosshores border. Through the highlighting of four key elements of polyentric governance, the political will, legal framework, support from the governance of a higher level and on the capacity structure, the case studies show that polyentric governance plays an important role in achieving three environmentally relevant SDG 16 targets , but these goals are silent about environmental government dimensions. Since many conflicts arise from the environmental and natural resource sector, we suggest that SDG comprises 16 indicators that are specifically directed at polyentric surroundings and governance of natural resources.

At least 40% of the people in the South African development community have no access to safe water and sanitary facilities, which makes them vulnerable to extended conflicts and disasters, including exposure to water diseases, other pandemics, poverty and human suffering. Although several international and African regional contracts support human rights for water and hygiene, the ability of the SADC regulation framework to enter into force is worrying. In fact, the available literature on the ability of the SADC to recognize these rights is sensibly recognized, fragmented and sparse. In this article, a new governance approach to implement the sustainable target 6 of the United Nations Agenda 2030 is examined. The article argues that the compulsion could be a conclusive, regional reaction to the continuous development of water and sanitary rights in the SADC region through regional destination.

Water and sanitation are the core of sustainable development, and the range of services that provide poverty reduction, economic growth and environmental sustainability. However, in recent decades, overexploitation, pollution and climate change have led to severe water stress in places around the world. ||| Today, 2.2 billion people lack access to drinking water safely, and more than 4.2 billion people lack sanitation administered safely. . Climate change is exacerbating the situation, with an increase in disasters such as floods and droughts. 80 percent of wastewater in the world returns to the ecosystem without being treated or reused, and 70 percent of the world's natural wetland extension has been lost, including significant loss of freshwater species. ||| While SDG 6 is the most recent iteration of the United Nations objective to address water -related problems, the issue has been a concern in the United Nations. Declaring that all people have the right to access drinking water in quantities and quality equal to their basic needs. The importance of water was even more raised by the international supply of drinking water and the sanitation of the 1981 to 1990 and in 1992 at the UN Conference on Environment and Development in Rio de Janeiro is an independent body responsible for advising to the SG in all matters related to water with water. and sanitation and to promote action in these particular areas.

The convention on biological diversity 14 to "keep and use the oceans, seas and marine resources for sustainable development in a sustainable way" reiterates the quantitative element of Aichi Target 11 and, through the sub-plaids described, places further emphasis on the Economic and social context of global development. The complexity of the language of Aichi Target 11 is not reflected in SDG 14, leading to a potential scenario in which the knowledge and progress towards Aichi Target 11 will be diluted while the focus moves to the SDGs. This document presents the current knowledge and implementation of the qualitative elements of Aichi Target 11 and highlights the gaps in knowledge. We conclude that the progress carried out so far on the description and implementation of the qualitative objectives of Aichi Target 11 should be integrated into SDG 14 in order to strengthen global efforts for the conservation of marine biodiversity and support the wider vision for the sustainable development that " will transform our world ".

Rapid urbanization, increasingly rich lifestyles and changes in food consumption patterns and general economic growth trends are increasing the demand for resources and services and exerting increasing pressure on ecosystems throughout the region of Asia and the Pacific. Ecosystems are threatened throughout the region due to increasingly intensive expansion and agriculture, oil palm plantations and unsustainable rubber, fires, forest clearance, poorly regulated extractive industries, aquaculture and illegal trade in wild life. The total forest area has increased in Asia since 1990, but this figure hides the continuous loss of natural forests behind the expansion of planted forests, and subregional tendencies differ. Southeast Asia, for example, shows a greater rate of loss of forest coverage, as well as a reduction in biomass stocks, despite an increased area of ​​protected forests and stability in areas under forest management plans1. The number of threatened species of mammals and plants increased by more than 10 and 18 percent respectively in the last decade. Rural media are intimately connected and negatively affected by the deterioration of the health of terrestrial ecosystems. The drivers of the change in land use vary between subregions. The largest and most developed countries are more affected by large -scale agricultural development, while smaller countries, especially the developing states of the small islands, suffer from land degradation of small -scale activities such as the changing culture or urban expansion of population growth. The degradation of terrestrial ecosystems results in the loss of current and future benefits in terms of the multiple services provided by terrestrial ecosystems, even for rural livelihoods, reduction in disaster risk, water supply, food security and kidnapping of carbon. Finally, a key challenge identified in the Multiple Interesting Party Survey Disc2 was the need to guarantee the participation of the community and indigenous people to address the conservation and protection of biodiversity.

In view of the above work, this paper should be considered one step further in the process of indicator design, which can inspire the Formal SDG review process. The novelty and complexity of the SDG frameworks opens up a wide range of research opportunities, three of which we highlight. First, the threshold values ​​proposed here do not say much about whether the countries are on the right track to achieve SDG-2 goals, unless it is monitored over a longer period of time. Although SDG goals are the same for all countries, the paths that they follow will differ. Historical trends can offer indications of the future of a country, but there is no guarantee that past trends remain. Second, synergies and compromises between SDGs and analytical scales should be examined in order to inform coherent political design under different scenarios. Thirdly, agricultural trade between the countries examined in this paper earns more attention and has a direct impact on nutritional and environmental indicators, especially if the access and availability of food are taken into account through the short and long conditions. In all cases, the identification of research methods for combating the spatial and temporal scalar complexity of sustainability goals is of crucial importance.

The report examines the interactions between the various objectives and objectives, determining to what extent they reinforce or conflict with each other. This brief description of SDG 2 - the "Objective of the Entrance Level" for this evaluation - is followed by an overview of the target level interactions between SDG 2 and the other 16 SDGs. Taking into account all the underlying objectives of this entry target, there is a set of basic interactions between SDG 2 objectives and other SDGs, focusing on high -size or intense interactions based on the available scientific literature and expert knowledge. The typology and the scale of seven points to characterize the range of positive and negative interactions described in the initial chapter of this report are used to evaluate the selected interactions at the target level and the framework in which they usually occur. Explanatory examples from different areas of the world show how these connections are manifested in practice. Policy options that can boost positively and reduce negative interactions from now to 2030 onwards. The chapter concludes with a list of basic knowledge gaps related to the interactions studied.

The 2030 Agenda follows a universal approach and identifies countries in the global south and the global north that need transformation towards sustainability. Therefore, countries in the global North, such as Germany, have signed a commitment to implement sustainable development goals. This article aims to analyze how global goals that address urban developments are contextualized at the national level. Our findings show that only some of the original targets and indicators for SDG 11 are used in the German context; Thus, large adjustments were made according to the main sustainability challenges identified for Germany. In addition, our results show that the current contextualization of ODS 11 and sustainable urban development in Germany are still underway, and more changes and commitments need to be made.

In order to reduce poverty and to achieve goal 1 of the 2030 Agenda for sustainable development, the foreign trade flows of the federal states must be a driving force for productive activities, as suggested by the WTO. This work analyzes the development of international trade in goods and services between the least developed countries of Africa and customers and suppliers from other countries between 2005 and 2015, based on the information provided by Unctad and the World Bank. The results confirm a greater degree of commercial openness and in particular an increase in service imports. Overall, the data shows that the purchases made on the international market have a larger border effectively on GDP than sales, which leads to the conclusion that changes in trading policy are necessary at both international and national level. Measures should aim to ensure that the growing integration of these economies into the world trade system does not lead to continuing deficits in the trade balance, but on the contrary contributes to GDP growth and reducing the reduction in poverty.

Our Freeport approach believes that effective water management means maximizing our water Ection so that we can minimize our use of new freshwater. This article is built on the following research issues: Could sustainability protocols constitute a solution to the realization of SDG11? We emphasize that, on the one hand, the SDGs are guidelines to support the development of sustainable policies and thus approach all the elements that can affect them, and on the other hand, sustainability protocols are evaluation tools To promote the concern for sustainability while remaining targeted on the built environment. In the Italian regulatory context, the document emphasizes how this difference in terms of concentration and scale means that they do not overlap and strengthen each other with regard to certain aspects, more linked to energy and air pollution problems and less to social aspects of sustainability. Even if there is not always a direct relationship between the criteria for evaluating protocols and the indicators of SDG11, it is possible to conclude that sustainability protocols can facilitate the achievement of SDG11 objectives, acting as a key for Implementation of sustainable cities and help structure the process leading to sustainability in a broader framework.

At Eaton, we usually focus on innovations that can help us reach a low carbon economy, but we also like to show how our employees can choose to support a sustainable lifestyle. With this in mind, all Eaton employees have access to the Eaton Go Green mobile application, which allows them to join teams to improve the environment and measure their impact. Every quarter, we have challenges that encourage employees to get involved and see how small actions increase. We tracked how much carbon and water waste were reduced by actions taken by individuals. Although these metrics do not contain our corporate metrics, they are a significant statistic for individuals and teams trying to measure their environmental footprint. Eaton's green guardians are a group of active employees of approximately sustainability -focused people. To promote sustainable lifestyles, this group leads projects and events throughout the installation, such as composting programs that install LED lighting and slow OW taps planting community gardens and local navigable road cleaning. The group communicates regularly through an open internal forum, where employees share tips and photos of articles. Discussions vary from requesting advice on how to reduce personal fossil fuel use and share low carbon diet recipes. A large and different country, such as India, where inequality takes many forms, faces a greater challenge to achieve SDG 10. In India, there are income inequalities and inequalities of access to gender, religion, caste and region . However, based on data availability, five indicators have been identified in accordance with SDG targets 10.1, 10.2 and 10.4 to assess India's performance to SDG 10. Based on SDG rating for reduced inequalities between 29 states, 3 States are categorized as successes. 20 States are recognized as front runners and 2 states are designated as candidates. Although India has shown progress in achieving target 10, it has a long way to go to achieve equality between 10% and the minimum 40% of households in both urban and rural areas. It still needs to ensure the same access to opportunities for women, minorities and transsexuals.

Food systems require and influence three main societal results - economic vitality, environmental sustainability and social inclusion and human health. Economic vitality is made by various policies, such as trade and employment, are influenced by food systems and vice versa. Environmental sustainability occurs thanks to the protection of ecosystem and natural capital services which in turn have co-displays with food systems. Social inclusion and human health depend very well on food security, nutrition, food culture and animal welfare. Although a change in the system can bring multiple results, these results may not be all considered to be progress. A nutritional intervention can have an involuntary consequence for environmental, economic and social results or an economic incentive can have deep impacts on the environment or the basis of natural resources.

In response to growing political concerns about rising inequality inside and between countries, the objectives of sustainable development include what seems to be an innovative target to reduce inequality in the form of SDG 10. This study used office research To investigate what led to its integration by analyzing the negotiation process on objectives, objectives and indicators. The results show that OCPs have requested a global rule to reduce the sharp economic inequality in the context of an autonomous goal. On the other hand, the states part of the UN working group in SDG that frame inequality simply as social integration, which will be dealt with throughout the context. SDG 10 was included when developing countries, unattracted by the lack of targets between the country of inequality, joined the OCP. In the nominal value, the goal carries a global transformation of a global rule, but this is misleading, as states have denied a target that measured the gap between incomes up and down. Combined with watered goals and indicators, this led to poor alignment between the title of the goal and its content. This shows that despite the open nature of OWG, the Member States remained by far the most important decision-making managers and successfully used a "Ignore-And-Reframe" strategy to maintain politically sensitive proposals by SDG10. An exciting way to further explore would be if SDG10 inclusion makes a global rule to reduce the sharp economic inequality in the future more likely and what it would need to achieve this.

The analysis of existing monitoring activities shows that the greatest challenges that cause data gaps are associated with the novelty of most indicators and their complexity. There are no conceptual problems regarding the methodologies of the indicator, but challenging conditions that complicate data collection. A key element to increase data availability in the coming years is the construction of national capacity, since national data build the basis to monitor global indicators. In addition, the scope of data sources can be extended, for example, aligning national and regional initiatives with global objectives, allowing common monitoring efforts and, therefore, reducing the load load of countries. In this context, the water and health protocol can potentially increase the availability of data in the Paneuropea region. The comparison of the SDG 6 indicators and the current protocol report template indicates that there are already aspects that require very similar data. However, small modifications could improve these overlaps and facilitate the common use of national monitoring capacity and the data collected. The comparison of the country's current reports and the latest JMP progress reports suggests that several parts of the protocol do not completely exploit this potential.

This chapter focuses on how the participatory speculative design was established within the context of healthy aging in Malaysia. Four workshops were developed and implemented with a variety of interested parties, from older people to technical experts involved in the development of technologies and policies on aging and health. Participatory workshops led to the development of some emerging prototypes by researchers as proof of concept. At the same time, the workshop discovered a series of challenges involved in the introduction of a speculative design such as a participatory approach to address current problems with political implications, ranging from the localized context of policy formulation to the preparation of the participants .

Rapid urbanization has brought many problems, including housing scarcity, traffic congestion, air pollution and lack of public space. To solve these problems, the United Nations proposed “the 2030 agenda for sustainable development”, which contains 17 sustainable development goals that cover three dimensions: economy, society and the environment. Among them, the target of sustainable development 11, “making human cities and settlements inclusive, safe, resilient and sustainable” can be measured at the city level. So far, SDG11 has not yet three rooms of the data needed to accurately evaluate progress towards the goal. In this article, we locate the SDG11 indicators and collected land observation data, statistical data and monitoring data at the city and county levels to build a better urban sustainable development evaluation structure. Overall, we found that Haikou and Sanya were close to reaching sustainable development goals, while other cities were still at a distance. In Hainan province, there was a spatial distribution pattern of high levels of development in the north and south, but low levels in the middle and west. Through index I of Hainan Province, we found that the sustainable development of Hainan province was not yet part of integrated development planning. The sustainable development assessment structure and the location methods proposed in this article at the city and county levels provide references to Hainan's sustainable development. At the same time, it also provides a reference for the evaluation of sustainable development goals at the county level in the cities of China and even the world.

The document describes the experience of the global partnership partner on the introduction of integrated management of integrated water resources and water safety. The concept of "sustainable management", in the Russian version of Water SDG6, is translated as "rational use" but nobody can explain why. We suggest that such a misunderstanding has occurred since Ukrainian decision makers are still perceived only as water users who are not obliged to achieve any development objective. Therefore, they are quite comfortable with the existing regulatory approach to the management of water resources in which the objectives comply with the defined standards and guarantee water safety, which is understood as an absence of a water risk exclusively for the man, rather than the environment in general. Keeping in mind that true science begins with measurable values ​​and recognizing that it is not possible to manage if it cannot be measured, we propose to change this false understanding of water safety and sustainability which is inherent in the obsolete concept of "rational use". This shift is possible only by moving on to a measurable approach to the objectives and management of risks in water policy.

SDG1 presents to the global community an important but highly challenging goal. By discussing the potential of tourism to contribute to SDG1 to "final poverty in all its forms everywhere," the multidimensional nature of poverty should be considered rather than focusing only on economic deprivation. Specifically, we need to change focus beyond how tourism can promote economic growth, provide jobs and income, considering sociopolitical aspects of poverty and how structural inequalities are preventing people's development. The contradictions involved in poor people, in poor places, with bad labor rights, wearing smiling faces to serve rich guests of colonial ex -poders and clean their messes, should not be neglected if we are genuinely interested in challenging negative aspects of tourism global and making it more equitable and sustainable in the future. Thus, if governments and tourist participants want to make more than pay attention to SDG1, they will need to make some significant changes in the way they work. This article will be inspired by Fiji tourism business that are addressing SDG1 and related goals and discuss how they have the potential to contribute to long -term sustainable development.

Social inequalities are intensifying globally and the expansion of divisions are linked to civil disorders. Disadvantaged ethnic and religious groups experience poor access, representation and results from public services such as health care and education. As mechanisms for social participation and citizenship, public services are fundamental for inclusive and sustainable companies. In this document we present the results of a systematic review on strategies for the inclusion of ethnic and religious minority community, often neglected populations in terms of sustainable development activities. We focus on four public service areas: education, health, local government and police services and identify rehearsals gaps. Our general objective is to sensitize and cause the debate, reflection and subsequently the action towards the inclusion of ethnic and religious minorities disadvantaged within public services. The inclusion of the public service inclusion have been identified through a review of the global tests and four specific reviews of the country conducted by the network of socially inclusive cities: academics, NGOs, policies and professionals of India, Kenya, Nigeria, Vietnam and the United Kingdom. The proofs published were integrated by national and international seminars that involved over 230 pertinent interested parties. We specifically explored the intersectional experience relating to gender, age and migration. 56 publications have been identified for the global review, mainly in health and education. The Macro Arena has been identified as three distinct but interconnected levels through which exclusion is operational. Three general framework appeared fundamental for successful ethnic and religious initiatives: accounting of the social context; Multiple strategies for the reform of the system; and collaboration with disadvantaged communities. Inclusion strategies are needed that face macro, meso and micro level exclusion drivers to reach the aspirations of 10 SDG. The involvement of the communities concerned is the key to their success.

The objective of sustainable development 2 concerns the end of hunger, the achievement of food safety and the improvement of nutrition and the promotion of sustainable agriculture. SDGs mention only some political indicators and SDG2 in particular is largely devoid of political considerations to end hunger and achieve food safety. The Nobel Prize award Amartya Sen observed the absence of famine in democracies notoriously, suggesting that a democratic system provides checks and balances that prevent famine. His observation has aroused further debates and triggered empirical studies in recent years. Going beyond the hypothesis of Sen, this essay examines other political factors that would explain vulnerability to famine and which must be faced more explicitly in SDG 2 and similar initiatives. Taking the case of shepherds in the distant region of Ethiopia, this research explores selected political determinants of vulnerability to famine. The war of Eritrea-Ethiopia and the consequent closure to the borders had a harmful effect on the sustenance of the pastors away-twolls were deprived of a market and a reliable source of income. In addition, distant shepherds were set aside by the informal salty sector on which they used to rely. The state has facilitated this expropriation, leaving the shepherds even more vulnerable to famine. I argue that political considerations are crucial to successfully end to hunger and reach food safety. The essay uses a qualitative design of Case Study and is based on a doctoral thesis.

The analysis of the existing monitoring activities shows that the greatest challenges that cause data gaps are associated with the novelty of most indicators and their complexity. There are no conceptual problems in relation to the methods of the indicator, but rather challenging conditions that complicate data acquisition. A key element in increasing data availability within the next few years is national capacity formation, since national data form the basis for monitoring the global indicators. In addition, the extent of the data sources can be expanded by reconciling national and regional initiatives with the global goals, which reduces joint monitoring efforts and thus the reporting of the countries. In this context, the protocol of water and health may increase data availability in the Pan-European region. The comparison of the SDG 6 indicators and the current reporting template of the protocol shows that there are already aspects that require very similar data. However, slight changes could improve these overlaps and facilitate frequent use of national surveillance capacity and the collected data. The comparison of the current country reports and the latest JMP progress reports suggests that several parties of the protocol do not fully exploit this potential.

Avoiding, reducing and inverting the degradation of the soil and the restoration of degraded land is an urgent priority to protect biodiversity and ecosystem services that are vital for life on earth. To stop and reverse the current trends in the degradation of the territory, it is immediately necessary to improve national skills to undertake quantitative assessments and mapping of their degraded lands, as required by the Sustainable Development objectives. In response to this problem, this document presents an initial overview of an innovative approach to monitor the degradation of the territory on a national scale in accordance with the SDG15.3.1 indicator using Landsat's observations using a data cube, but further works are required to improve the calculation of the three under the point of the infants.

Poverty is one of the most pressing issues in the world, and progress in reducing poverty has been reflected due to the global Covid-19 pandemic. In this chapter, the authors define the goal of sustainable development 1, without poverty and discuss how sports industry actors can play a role in reducing poverty. The authors offer an overview of the Sustainable Living Framework, a holistic framework for understanding how sustainable means of living can deal with poverty. Following an outline of the basic elements of SLF and how the frame is associated with SDG 1 and sports, authors underline the ways forward and the possible challenges of the use of SLF for empirical research on poverty, Sport and SDG 1. They end up in chapter by identifying some sports industry actors working to achieve SDG 1.

The first writings in Islamic economy represented a large and, would say, the utopian image of the type of societal development which would result from the implementation of Islamic social and economic theory. However, despite the emergence of the Islamic economy in a modern sense in the 1960s, we now note that the only demonstration which represents an Islamic alternative to dominant neoclassical development is the Islamic banking and financial industry. However, the developments in the Islamic financial services industry indicate that it has converged on conventional finance, which, no doubt, contributes to the financialization of the economy, consequently. Consequently, he failed to fulfill the institutional and political aspirations of the Islamic economic system. This declaration is studied with an empirical study. We note that initial Islamic banks have played a positive role in reducing income inequality, however, because Islamic finance has become a real force on the market, the financialization of industry could have contributed to inequality Income, therefore Islamic finance cannot significantly contribute to the realization of SDG 10, namely the reduction of inequalities.

We studied the action of image change and spectral flow operators in a zero zero operator grounding ring in the chiral co-fomology closed rope BST n = 2 and describe an infinite set of symmetry loads that acts on physical states. The transformations of physical string states are compared to the symmetries of self-studio gravity, which is the effective rope field theory n = 2 closed. We derive all the infinitesimal symmetries of self-dimensional gravity equations in space-dimensional and introduce an infinite hierarchy of displacement flows into the space of self-tape metric modules. Dependence on module parameters can be recovered by resolving the ODS hierarchy equations associated with an infinite set of Abelian symmetries generated recursively of translations. These non -lococal abelian symmetries are shown to coincide with the hidden symmetries of Abelian ropes responsible for the disappearance of the most dispersed amplitudes. Therefore, n = 2 string theory "predicts" not only self-tape gravity, but also the SDG hierarchy.

In response to the growing political concerns about increasing inequality within and among countries, sustainable development objectives include what seems to be an innovative objective to reduce inequality in the form of SDG 10. This study used desktop research for Explore what led to its inclusion when analyzing the negotiation process on the objective, the objectives and indicators. The results show that the OSCs demanded a global norm to reduce vertical economic inequality as part of an independent objective. On the other hand, the states part of the UN Open Working Group in SDGs framed frame inequality simply as social inclusion, which will be addressed throughout the framework. The SDG 10 was included when developing countries, dissatisfied with the lack of inequality objectives between countries, joined the OSC. To the nominal value, the objective transmits a global transformative norm, but this is misleading since the states rejected an objective that measured the gap between the upper and lower income. In combination with diluted objectives and indicators, this led to a misalignment between the title of the objective and its content. This shows that despite the open nature of the OWG, the Member States greatly remained the most influential decision makers and successfully used a strategy of "ignoring and focusing again" to maintain politically sensitive proposals outside SDG10. An exciting route to explore more thoroughly would be if the inclusion of SDG10 makes a global norm to reduce vertical economic inequality in the future, and what would be needed to achieve this.

In this point of view, it is argued that for the Palestinian people under the current political situation of the Israeli occupation, the Palestinian people cannot be achieved in order to ensure the availability and sustainable management of water and sanitary facilities that the goal 6 that the availability and Sustainable management of water and sanitary facilities should ensure for everyone. Through the practice of hydro hegemony, Israel controls all water resources in Israel and the occupied Palestinian territory and thus refuses the water sovereignty to the Palestinians. This is shown by three case studies: the Jordan valley; The settlements in the West Bank; and gaza. The policy of water in Israel and the occupied Palestinian territory is best understood as part of the dynamics of settler colonialism, in which ethnic cleansing is achieved by expropriating essential resources. The authors discuss what role the international scientific community can play in the support of the Palestinian water sovereignty and thus the SDG 6.

This article begins with the promotion of the opportunities of the objectives of sustainable growth, which guided international anti -poverty action between 2000 and 2015. Then, by analysis of SDG 1 - the target aimed at ending poverty in all forms Everywhere - he argues that while SDGs are making significant developments in relation to MDGs, they are violated by weak goals that provide little evidence of how the goal will be achieved and by whom. This basic defect, further supports the article, reflects two deeper, fundamental problems that apply to SDGs as a whole. The first is that SDGs make it easy to slow down governments to carry out human rights and the second is that SDGs do not specify a clear division of work, which is a duty based on human rights to eliminate severe poverty requires essentially.

The end of poverty is the first of the 17 sustainable development objectives of the United Nations. Universities are strategic spaces to promote SDGs, training, research and awareness -raising capacity for the implementation of sustainable actions, helping to reduce inequalities and, considerably, to promote cities and communities durable. This article aims to respond to the way in which the public university of Navarre contributes to the promotion of the 1st SOD, what mechanisms for the end of poverty approve on its territory, and what can we learn from these experiences. To this end, a case study was carried out according to qualitative techniques. This work analyzes the strategies implemented, such as the integration of social clauses for responsible recruitment, the development of applied research and teaching or participation in the network. From this example, certain engaging lessons will be extracted to solve this problem in other contexts, promoting their consolidation and identifying the obstacles that can hinder their spread.

While Kenya strives to maintain momentum in its race for the realization of sustainable development by 2030, its food security situation remains precarious. If Kenya wants to reach zero hunger by 2030, it will take efforts to increase the gains made. Currently, the effects of climatic shocks, COVID-19, the invasion of locusts and an economy that does not develop as expected, continue to exacerbate food insecurity. Although there have been gains on long-term rains over the years, these gains are lost due to an economy that fluctuates and was first weakened due to post-electoral violence in 2007/ 2008 and now even more because of COVID-19 This weak economy has a negative impact on access, not only for food, but also its availability. It is estimated that at the end of this year, many Kenyans will be insecure food requiring humanitarian assistance. While the majority of Kenyans have access to food, they are still unable to respond to the recommended rations. Many Kenyans have access to affordable food, making food regimes less and less nutritional. Although Kenya is currently an economy of lower-medium income, it still has around 238,000 in an emergency phase. The arid and semi-arid lands have the highest levels of food insecurity. The evolution of climate models has led to poor performance of short rains. Climate change has a negative impact on the already fragile food security situation. The increase in food insecurity levels threatens to cancel the gains made in Kenya's progress towards zero hunger. While challenges continue to persist, the United Nations World Food Program works with the Kenya Government to increase the construction efforts of a sustainable food system that will ensure sustainability in Kenya food and nutrition security. Consequently, this study seeks to assess the role of PAM in the achievement of SDG 2 in Kenya. The study relied on primary and secondary data.

HHS Sustainability Strategy Vision Our sustainability strategy is supported by four ex -focus areas. This focus area seeks to capture the opportunity to improve our product portfolio through more sustainable products and application methods that improve energy efficiency and diminish build cycle emissions. We have partnered with cement and lemon manufacturers to test low carbon products to reduce our scope emissions and we are committed to reaching the netzero emissions of our products. Focus on the climate environment of the area, ambition is to reduce scope and emissions and continually improve the use of resources. This focus area aims to reduce our scope and emissions reach Netzero emissions from operations and continually improve the use of resources through enhanced environmental management and strategic supply of materials. A -chave element here is the circular economy and we have three sub -flaxes focused on this subject. These are a principle without residues of virgin materials, a brick brick approach and an build -up approach. Social Focus Area Safety and HH people seek zero damage to our people and want to be an attractive employer. This area of ​​focus strives for zero damage to our people through behavioral levers and improved automation, and remains an attractive employer to attract retain and develop our talent pool. The area of ​​focus on HH business integrity conducts business in an ethical and socially responsible way. To boost the anti -confidence guidelines of laws and sustainable supply, this focus area aims to ensure that we always conduct business in an ethical and socially responsible way.

Annual Report on the Sustainability Climate Why imports Freeport acknowledges that climate change raises considerable close and long -term challenges for society and for our own operational and financial performance. Mining is energy and generates significant emissions of greenhouse gases gei that contribute to climate change. However, copper plays an essential role in the technologies necessary to develop and offer low carbon energy, including solar energy and energy technologies, which are fundamental to support the transition of global energy to fulfill the Paris Agreement on the climate change. Our approach as one of the world's largest copper producers, Freeport, includes its critical role in the low coal energy transition. We continue to supply the global copper economy produced in a responsible manner and operate in a way that manages and mitigates our GHG emissions and other climatic risks. In we published our inaugural climate report, it established our first objective of GHG emission reduction for the Americas and promised to align our climatic strategy and revelations related to the recommendations of the working group on Financial Disseminations of Climater TCFD in the coming years. We also formalize our climate change strategy that is based on three pillars, reduction of resilience and contribution. Reduction we strive to handle mitigation and reduce our GHG emissions when possible. As a first step, we established our initial public objective to reduce our GHG emissions in the Americas by a ton of copper cathode from our baseline. Resilience We strive to improve our resistance to physical and transition risks associated with climate change for our operations our host communities and our interested parties. This includes working proactively to analyze and prepare for extreme climatic events of water stress and other impacts of climate change. Contribution we strive to be a positive taxpayer beyond our operational limits by producing copper and molybdenum for energy transition. This includes collaborating with partners in our value chain with the ultimate goal of meeting the objectives of the Paris Agreement. For more information about our climate approach, including our strategy, read our opening climate report available on our website. We will also publish our climate report at the end of this year. The copper produced in a responsible manner is necessary for the technologies necessary to develop and enable energy transition. The solar panels were installed in a church in the host community by the El Abra Operation in Chile.

RA International Resource Management Report Management Management Management of Resources by measuring carbon footprint in preparation for the target process we measured the carbon footprint for the first time. By providing us with a basic line for which we will identify the improvements, this project has created a steady foundation for our reference to sustainability in the coming years. In addition, the process has allowed us to identify carbon hotspots the areas in which we must focus on our improvement efforts and resources at the moment. Supplier and Sitesto insure a strong process that have involved the support of an experienced and highly committed UK -based green element consulting company. In January, the duty began to calculate the carbon footprint. Since the measurement of impacts across the company would be impossible, we have agreed to consider a cross -section of locations from which we could measure the overall carbon footprint. Six locations were selected by three criteria in mind the availability of important data to determine their functional limits and suitability for use as future examples of what we can achieve. Scope and results Our Counselors followed the GHG protocol the worlds used widely used greenhouse gas accounting standards for organisms. The scope of the projects included emissions of all measurable fuels that bought energy consumables and waste produced. At least 40% of people in the region of the Southern African development community do not have access to the water and safe hygiene-health services, making them vulnerable to prolonged conflicts and catastrophes, including exposure to diseases conducted by water, Other pandemics, poverty and human suffering. Although several international and African regional treaties support human rights to the waters and toilets -Sanitari, the ability of the SADC regulatory framework to give effect to these rights is worrying. In fact, the literature available on the ability of the SADC to significantly realize these rights is fragmented and poor. This article theoretically examines a new governance approach to the implementation of the sustainable objective 6 of the United Nations Agenda 2030. The article maintains that coercion through the "definition of the regional objectives" can provide a final and regional response to continuous development of water rights and hygienic -Sanitaries in the SADC region.

This article begins by highlighting the strengths of the sustainable development objectives, which have guided an international action against poverty between 2000 and 2015. Therefore, through an analysis of SDG 1 - the goal that aims to end the Poverty in all forms everywhere - claims that while the SDGs make important progress compared to the MDG, they are spoiled by weakly formulated objectives that provide few indications on how the goal will be achieved and by whom. This basic defect, also supports the article, is a reflection of two deeper basic problems that apply to the OSS as a whole. The first is that SDGs make it easy for governments to slow down the realization of human rights, and the second is that SDGs do not specify a clear division of labor, which is what is a duty based on human rights to eradicate serious poverty basically requires.

The analysis of existing surveillance activities shows that the greatest challenges causing data gaps are associated with the novelty of most indicators as well as their complexity. There are no conceptual problems concerning the methodologies of the indicator but rather difficult conditions that complicate data collection. A key element in the increase in data availability in the coming years is national capacity building, as national data strengthen the base to monitor global indicators. In addition, the extent of data sources can be extended, for example, by aligning national and regional initiatives with global objectives, allowing current monitoring efforts and thus reducing the country's declaration. In this context, the water and health protocol can potentially increase the availability of data in the pan -European region. The comparison of SDG 6 indicators and the current protocol report model indicates that there are already aspects that require very similar data. However, slight modifications could improve these overlaps and facilitate the common use of the national surveillance capacity and the data collected. The comparison of current countries reports and the latest JMP stage reports suggest that several parts of the protocol do not fully exploit this potential.

Our approach water is of crucial importance for our work and for the long -term sustainability of the company and our visiting communities. We cannot operate without water and Freeport understands the crucial importance of managing the effects of our activities on the availability and quality of the water and the rights of the rights of our visiting communities and indigenous neighbors. The Freeports Water Stewardship Program focuses on maximizing our water consumption together in our operating processes so that we can minimize our use of new fresh water from the natural environment. We also focus on relocating our water supply to more sustainable sources that have been recycled renewable and lower quality sources in order to minimize negative effects from our operation on water quality and availability in the local catchment areas and the development of access to previously unknown persons to support non -developed water resources. The UN predicts that 68% of the world's population will live in urban areas by 2050, compared to 55% today. Cities contribute to 70% of the world economy with proportional energy consumption and the consequent carbon emission. According to the World Bank, cities will generate 3.4 billion tons of solid waste by 2050, compared to 2 billion in 2016. The target of sustainable development 10 reduces inequality in and between countries, was among the last SDGs to be added. The ODS 10 was largely a reaction to the growing attention given to the rude disparities observed worldwide and the political reaction to these disparities. Although it may be understood as an appeal to some redistribution of wealth globally, it is unlikely that large -scale redistribution through taxation or other means will be politically viable as a solution to inequality soon. It is more plausibly interpreted as a request to reduce inequalities - those that prevent people and states from having a fair shot in the conquest of prosperity and development. In the nation states, we can see this as a request for a developmental rights approach - an approach that seeks to give people the capabilities to succeed, and remove political and social factors, such as discrimination and repression, that prevent them from to reach your potential. Internationally, it is related to the concept of the right to development, which puts obligations to assist the states developed to help the poor. International institutions such as the World Bank and the United Nations have a mandate to promote these rights and can act as intervening institutions, giving credibility to this impetus for the recognition of developmental rights. The targets defined by SDG 10 are more vague and aspirational than most other SDGs, but the end of serious wealth inequalities can be seen as a fundamental issue that makes many other SDGs possible. As such, SDG 10 imposes specific duties on parties that can make it reality.

The 2030 Sustainable Development Program is a prospect for the future development of all countries of the world. Its heart is to set up the objectives of sustainable development for the year 2030 and to develop a series of institutional mechanisms around the SDGs to promote its implementation. The SDGs include 17 objectives, whose ODD 11 is to make cities and human colonies inclusive, safe, resilient and sustainable. The green building can play a positive role in the implementation of the ODD 11. However, the entire process of developing green construction involves several stakeholders and various professional fields, which play different roles where can be positive synergies or negative compromises throughout the process. This article uses Nexus approaches to clarify how several stakeholders and professions interact with each other in the development of green construction in order to promote the ODD 11.

As Kenya is striving to keep the moment in their race to achieve sustainable development by 2030, their food security situation remains precarious. If Kenya reaches zero hunger by 2030, he will need efforts to expand the gains obtained. Currently, the effects of climate shocks, Covid-19, grasshopper invasion and an economy that is not growing as expected, continue to exacerbate food insecurity. Although long-term rainfall has been gains over the years, these gains are being lost because of an economy that floats and was first weakened because of post-election violence in 2007/2008 and now even more because of Covid- 19 . This weak economy is negatively affecting access, not only food, but also its availability. It is estimated that by the end of this year many Kenyans will be insecure foods that require humanitarian assistance. Although most Kenyans have access to food, they still cannot meet the recommended rations. Many Kenyans have access to affordable foods, making diets less and less nutritional. Although Kenya is currently a lower income economy, it still has about 238,000 in the emergency phase. Arid and semi-arid lands have the highest levels of food insecurity. The change of climate patterns has led to a bad performance of short rain. Climate change is negatively impacting the already fragile food security situation. The growing levels of food insecurity threaten to deny the gains obtained in Kenya's progress toward zero hunger. While challenges continue to persist, the United Nations World Food Program works in conjunction with the Kenyan government to increase efforts to build a sustainable food system that will ensure sustainability in Kenya's food and nutritional security. Therefore, this study seeks to evaluate the role of PMA in obtaining SDG 2 in Kenya. The study was based on primary and secondary data.

Food systems require and influence three main societal results - economic vitality, environmental sustainability and social inclusion and human health. Economic vitality is made by various policies, such as trade and employment, are influenced by food systems and vice versa. Environmental sustainability occurs thanks to the protection of ecosystem and natural capital services which in turn have co-displays with food systems. Social inclusion and human health depend very well on food security, nutrition, food culture and animal welfare. Although a change in the system can bring multiple results, these results may not be all considered to be progress. A nutritional intervention can have an involuntary consequence for environmental, economic and social results or an economic incentive can have deep impacts on the environment or the basis of natural resources.

Goal 11 of the goals for sustainable development, including safe, resistant and sustainable cities, including, including, safe, resilient and sustainable goals, international normative guidance on sustainable development and urban government management. This chapter argues that the goal 11 of the SDGs is a clear expression of the urban turn, so to speak in global government. The article contextualizes the backdrop, in which SDG 11 is inserted, as well as the goals of goal 11. The chapter also discovers the inherent contradictions of SDG 11, since not all sub -destinations can be reached at the same time and without being able to negatively influence some of the others Sdgs. For example, the ideas of "security" and "inclusiveness" could be in conflict. The chapter closes with a critical view of some of the general implementation risks and challenges associated with SDG 11.
